Snowdon Cairns (Dartmoor).name: Snowdon Cairns (Dartmoor)
Snowdon Cairns (Dartmoor).description: Four cairns on Dartmoor in a rough north/south line, each cairn gets smaller as you go towards the north.  The three southern cairns are spaced 120m apart, the smallest northern one is 175m away and not marked on the OS map.

Shell Middens at Westward Ho!.name: Shell Middens at Westward Ho!
Shell Middens at Westward Ho!.description: Mesolithic shell middens at the south end of Westward Ho! Beach (Mesolithic to Late Neolithic - 8000 BC to 2201 BC (Between)) No evidence remained in 2002.

Mardon Down Mortar Pit.name: Mardon Down Mortar Pit
Mardon Down Mortar Pit.description: What looks like a cairn close to the junction of footpaths on the top of Mardon Down is in fact a mortar pit, made by troops based here in the build up to D Day during the second world war.

East Lowton settlement.name: East Lowton settlement
East Lowton settlement.description: Four lovely hut circles, near Fernworthy on Dartmoor. So easy to get to and so rewarding to see, One of them is written on the 1:25000 OS map as a cairn circle, but it's now classed as another hut, which it is.

Laughter Tor Longstone.name: Laughter Tor Longstone
Laughter Tor Longstone.description: A large standing stone stands 2.4 metres tall on the slopes of Laughter Tor, at the head of one double stone row, with remains of a second smaller row nearby.

Second Roborough Down Earthworks.name: Second Roborough Down Earthworks
Second Roborough Down Earthworks.description: This is a circular earth work approximately 15m diameter. It is located on Roborough Down about 200m ESE of the main Roborough Down Earthwork (see nearby sites on our page), on the Eastern side of the A386. It is a short walk from a nearby car park and the immediately surrounding gorse, bracken and brambles are trimmed by somebody so that it is accessible and visible.

Dornafield Tumulus.name: Dornafield Tumulus
Dornafield Tumulus.description:
Round Barrow(s) in Devon.
 A Tumulus and two mounds are marked on the OS map just to the East of Dornafield, an ancient house with a popular caravan park business attached to it.

Bellever Tor 10.name: Bellever Tor 10
Bellever Tor 10.description: Only one side of this cist remains. It consists of a slab of granite standing upright to a to height of 0.75m. It is 0.8m wide and 0.2m thick and appears to be an end-stone. At its foot is a slab which is partially buried and it was impossible to take its dimensions.

Kestor Settlement.name: Kestor Settlement
Kestor Settlement.description: On the slopes of Kestor, Chagford Comon, are the remains of a large ancient settlement with around twenty-seven hut circles. Apart from the major bronze age remains to be found, evidence of settlement dating back to the Neolithic and even before have been found here. The remains of many huts can be seen, but perhaps more impressive are the associated field systems and boundary walls.

Throwleigh Common prehistoric settlement.name: Throwleigh Common prehistoric settlement and field system
Throwleigh Common prehistoric settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Lee Moor Settlement.name: Lee Moor Settlement
Lee Moor Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Brent Fore Hill.name: Brent Fore Hill
Brent Fore Hill.description: On the hillside rising from the East Glaze brook opposite to the Corringdon Ball complex, can be seen the remains of this much ruined double row.

Eylesbarrow.name: Eylesbarrow
Eylesbarrow.description: The remains of two very large oval cairns on the summit of Eylesbarrow. The easternmost, called Eylesbarrow, measures 28m east to west and 26m north to south with a height of 1.8m. The other measures 20m east to west and 22m north to south and is 1.2 m high.

Yellowmead.name: Yellowmead
Yellowmead.description: Four Concentric Stone Circles in Devon. This site was restored in 1921 and consists of four concentric stone circles, one of which surrounded a cairn, now badly ruined. A stone row runs to the south-west.

Laughter Tor row 2.name: Laughter Tor row 2
Laughter Tor row 2.description: There are two stone rows at Laughter Tor. This stone row is also a double row, and is located 12m W of the longstone parallel with this row but just 5 pairs of stones barely show above the turf.  [Laughter Tor 1, also a double row, has its own site page - see the 'nearby sites' list below].

Glasscombe Ball North (North Cairn).name: Glasscombe Ball North (North Cairn)
Glasscombe Ball North (North Cairn).description: This cairn is located at the northern end of the Glasscombe Ball North stone row.

Wigford Down 5.name: Wigford Down 5
Wigford Down 5.description: One of two cairn circles, both in a raised platform. (See our nearby sites list for the other.) It has a ring of large stones with a cist cover in the centre. Diameter 7.62m. This site could also be a hut circle - it is unclear whether the large slab is actually a cist cover or not.

Legis Tor Ossuary.name: Legis Tor Ossuary
Legis Tor Ossuary.description: An intriguing structure consisting of two very large parallel slabs on Legis Tor. The site was discovered by William D. Lethbridge who suggests it might be an ossuary. This is quite clearly a man made structure. The two very large parallel slabs look very much like they are an artificial construction rather than natural. One end has a clearly built up wall to form a structure.

North Brentor Well.name: North Brentor Well
North Brentor Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Stalldown Encircled Cairn.name: Stalldown Encircled Cairn
Stalldown Encircled Cairn.description: Cairn to the west of Stalldown Stone Row

St Petrock's Well Devon.name: St Petrock's Well Devon
St Petrock's Well Devon.description: St. Petrock's Well in Devon is difficult to trace despite being marked on the OS map. The site is associated with the saint on his journey to Rome.

Cairn At Head of Drizzlecombe Row 4.name: Cairn At Head of Drizzlecombe Row 4

Ipplepen Iron Age Settlement.name: Ipplepen Iron Age Settlement
Ipplepen Iron Age Settlement.description: An Iron Age settlement unearthed in Devon has been described as one of the most important finds of its kind. It was prompted by the chance discovery of Roman coins in fields at Ipplepen, near Newton Abbot about five years ago. Archaeologists who have been excavations for several years say it is the first of its kind in the county.

Corn Ridge Stone Ring Cairn Circle.name: Corn Ridge Stone Ring Cairn Circle

Chittaford Down Platform Cairn Circle an.name: Chittaford Down Platform Cairn Circle and Cist

Cator Common Cairn Circle.name: Cator Common Cairn Circle
Cator Common Cairn Circle.description: Cairn with surrounding circle of stones on Cator Common, to the east of Bellever Bridge, Dartmoor.

West Wykes Farm Tau and Latin Crosses.name: West Wykes Farm Tau and Latin Crosses

St Andrew's Cross (South Tawton).name: St Andrew's Cross (South Tawton)
St Andrew's Cross (South Tawton).description: Alleged Ancient Cross and Cross Incised Grave Slab in Devon

Chagford Cross.name: Chagford Cross
Chagford Cross.description: This restored wayside cross has been re-purposed as a war memorial, and sits towards the north-eastern end of the churchyard of St Michael The Archangel in Chagford.

South Harton Cross.name: South Harton Cross
South Harton Cross.description: Ancient Cross on Dartmoor. At some time it was split down the middle from top to bottom, probably to form a pair of gateposts. In the 19th century the two halves were carefully re-assembled and the cross erected where we see it now. It probably came from somewhere along the lane that we followed from Lustleigh via Higher Combe and Sanduck

Standing Stone Near Cairn at Head of Dri.name: Standing Stone Near Cairn at Head of Drizzlecombe Row 4

Down Ridge Outlier.name: Down Ridge Outlier
Down Ridge Outlier.description: Almost 100 metres to the southeast of Down Ridge stone circle is a small standing stone, just under a metre tall.

Yar Tor Enclosure.name: Yar Tor Enclosure
Yar Tor Enclosure.description: At the northern part of the summit of Yar Tor is seen to be the remains of what is classified as a "Tor Enclosure", thought to be of neolithic origins.

Butterdon Down Cairns.name: Butterdon Down Cairns
Butterdon Down Cairns.description: On the top of Butterdon Hill are remains of several cairns.

Butterdon Down West.name: Butterdon Down West
Butterdon Down West.description: Likely Standing Stone on the western slopes of Butterdon Down, a couple of miles north of Moretonhampstead in Devon.

White Ridge Standing Stone.name: White Ridge Standing Stone
White Ridge Standing Stone.description: Possible fallen standing stone on Dartmoor.

Ryder's Hill.name: Ryder's Hill
Ryder's Hill.description: There are the remains of a low cairn upon the summit of RyderÂ’s hill which dates back to the Bronze Age.

Holy Trinity Well (Rackenford).name: Holy Trinity Well (Rackenford)
Holy Trinity Well (Rackenford).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Lewtrenchard Holy Well.name: Lewtrenchard Holy Well
Lewtrenchard Holy Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

The Buttery Stone.name: The Buttery Stone
The Buttery Stone.description: Standing stone, at the head of the valley near Buttery Corner on the Somerset Devon border, south western Exmoor.

Salcombe Hill Standing Stone.name: Salcombe Hill Standing Stone
Salcombe Hill Standing Stone.description: Standing Stone formed of local Breccia containing flint clasts.

Crow Tor.name: Crow Tor
Crow Tor.description: A kerbed cairn and cist on Dartmoor. The cairn consists of a stony, turf-covered mound, and measures 4.5m in diameter and 0.45m in height. There are traces of a retaining kerb of leaning, granite slabs to the northeast and south. The cist is set slightly to the north of the centre of the cairn.

Crownhill Down Cairn Circle.name: Crownhill Down Cairn Circle
Crownhill Down Cairn Circle.description: At SX57486026 is a cairn Circle set on a high point with distant views in most directions. It lies in very dense gorse in an area of close-cropped moorland turf and comprises an amorphous mound 0.5m high and 6.0m in diameter enclosed by an incomplete ring of boulders.

Huntingdon Warren Plane Crash Memorial C.name: Huntingdon Warren Plane Crash Memorial Cross

Huntingdon Warren Settlement.name: Huntingdon Warren Settlement
Huntingdon Warren Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Devil's Stone, Shebbear.name: Devil's Stone, Shebbear
Devil's Stone, Shebbear.description: The Shebbear Devil's stone in Devon is made from a type of quartz not found in the area, measures about six feet by four feet and weighs about a ton. It is a possible remnant of a standing stone and may have been an original foundation stone of Henscott Church.

St Helena Volcanic Stone.name: St Helena Volcanic Stone
St Helena Volcanic Stone.description: This interesting small memorial stands on a grassy patch near public benches overlooking  Plymouth Sound, below the rather grim, towering, Royal Citadel in Plymouth.

East Hill Promontory Fort.name: East Hill Promontory Fort
East Hill Promontory Fort.description: Promontory Fort in Devon. An Iron Age promontory fort is located on a spur between the East Okement River and the Moor Brook. The western side of the fort (the easiest direction to approach it) is defended by a well-preserved rampart and ditch. Inside the fort there are remains of an earlier enclosure.

Sister's Fountain.name: Sister's Fountain
Sister's Fountain.description: This elaborate structure was erected over a spring in the 19th century and named Sisters Fountain because the owners nieces liked to play in its vicinity.  The spring is reputed to have gushed forth from a spot where Joseph of Arimathea struck the ground with his staff.

Dripping Well (Barnstaple).name: Dripping Well (Barnstaple)
Dripping Well (Barnstaple).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Greystone.name: Greystone
Greystone.description: An impressive standing stone in a prominent position overlooking Woolacombe Bay.  It is possible to park on Sandy Lane at Seymour Villas, and then walk north-west through two small fields, which contained cattle when we visited.

Maggie Cross.name: Maggie Cross
Maggie Cross.description: Maggie Cross sometimes known as Postbridge Cross or St MargaretÂ’s Cross was believed to have stood at a nearby junction as a waymarker for the old trans-moor track, long before the B3212 was built. It is set into a wall opposite St Gabriel's Church, Postbridge.

Brisworthy.name: Brisworthy
Brisworthy.description: Twenty-four surviving stones of an original forty-two form an attractive and well-ordered circle 24.7m (81 feet) in diameter on Southern Dartmoor. The stones are graded from upward from the south to the north, with the tallest at the north being 1.1m (3 feet 8 inches) high.

Ringmoor Down.name: Ringmoor Down
Ringmoor Down.description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, a collection of ancient sites are to be found. These include Brisworthy stone circle, Ringmoor Down circle and row, several varied cairns and nearby settlements.

Giant's hill cairn.name: Giant's hill cairn
Giant's hill cairn.description: This cairn, situated just above the River Plym at 320.0m OD, consists of a mound of turf-covered stones 5.0m in diameter and 0.5m high. In the centre is a 1.0m square depression 0.4m deep.

Lower Hartor tor settlement..name: Lower Hartor tor settlement.
Lower Hartor tor settlement..description: Ancient Village or Settlement on Dartmoor in Devon

Challacombe Cross Settlement.name: Challacombe Cross Settlement
Challacombe Cross Settlement.description: Some very well preserved hut circles on the northern part of Shapley Common, near to Challacombe Cross, not far to the south of the main road across Dartmoor, the B3212.

Woodbury Castle.name: Woodbury Castle
Woodbury Castle.description: Woodbury Castle, a hillfort in Devon, dates back to about 500 to 300BC and is situated on a high point of Woodbury Common. Today a road runs through the middle of the earthwork ramparts.

Bellever Tor 4.name: Bellever Tor 4
Bellever Tor 4.description: Ring Cairn consisting of a circular rubble bank of about 11 m diameter.

Marden Down East.name: Marden Down East
Marden Down East.description: Head southwest up towards the top of Mardon Hill from the Headless Cross, and about halfway up there is the clear remains of a ring cairn.

Holne Ridge North.name: Holne Ridge North
Holne Ridge North.description: A cist within a cairn cemetery in Devon

Great Nodden.name: Great Nodden
Great Nodden.description: Cairn with Cist (no longer visible) in Devon

Cator Common Platform Cairn and Cist.name: Cator Common Platform Cairn and Cist

Sittaford Tor Cairn.name: Sittaford Tor Cairn
Sittaford Tor Cairn.description: Cairn with cist in Devon. Information about this site, the

Metherall Settlement.name: Metherall Settlement
Metherall Settlement.description: This is an ancient settlement near to the Fernworthy Reservoir on Dartmoor, in Devon. Eight fairly large hut circles and many other pound walls make up the settlement, with half of the huts now normally flooded by the Fernworthy Reservoir.

Bellever Tor 3.name: Bellever Tor 3
Bellever Tor 3.description: A long and difficult walk through long grass on very uneven ground to find this cairn marked on the map as "Cist". The nicely remaining cist has a single standing stone which is presumably remains of the surrounding cairn circle.

Upper Glazebrook.name: Upper Glazebrook
Upper Glazebrook.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Routrundle South.name: Routrundle South
Routrundle South.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Routrundle North.name: Routrundle North
Routrundle North.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Yealm Steps.name: Yealm Steps
Yealm Steps.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Scad Brook.name: Scad Brook
Scad Brook.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Walkhampton Enclosed Settlement.name: Walkhampton Enclosed Settlement
Walkhampton Enclosed Settlement.description: Hut circles 550m south of Foggintor quarries. A very fine settlement, set within a well built and substantial enclosure wall, enclosing an area of some 1.0ha. Five hut circles occur within the enclosure varying between 6-10m in diameter

Dean Moor Enclosed Settlement.name: Dean Moor Enclosed Settlement
Dean Moor Enclosed Settlement.description: Enclosed settlement on Dean Moor, Dartmoor excavated between 1954 and 1956, prior to construction of the reservoir.

Stalldown Settlement.name: Stalldown Settlement
Stalldown Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Riders Rings.name: Riders Rings
Riders Rings.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Gripper's Hill Enclosed Settlement.name: Gripper's Hill Enclosed Settlement
Gripper's Hill Enclosed Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Berry Castle (Huntshaw Wood).name: Berry Castle (Huntshaw Wood)
Berry Castle (Huntshaw Wood).description: Berry Castle is an Iron Age Hill Fort deep in the middle of Huntshaw Wood, near Great Torrington in North Devon.

Upper Erme Cairns.name: Upper Erme Cairns
Upper Erme Cairns.description: Considering all the number of ancient settlements and other signs of habitation in the Erme valley, there are relatively few cairns and other burial monuments to be found. For the entire 3.3 km length of the Upper Erme stone row, just four cairns, three of which are small and inconspicuous, are seemingly related to it, unlike the other great rows of the southern moor, which all have many cairns situated near to them.

Benjamy.name: Benjamy
Benjamy.description: Sitting at an altitude of 379 metres in the Exmoor National Park, Benjamy Stone Row is a double stone row comprising 8 small and medium sized stones forming a row of length 16 metres.  The row is orientated at 45 degrees and the site looks over the sea.

Stalldown South East.name: Stalldown South East
Stalldown South East.description: A scheduled ancient monument this single stone row comprises 7 stones making up a row of 21 metres in length.

Lakehead Hill SE Stone Row.name: Lakehead Hill SE Stone Row
Lakehead Hill SE Stone Row.description: Located in the Dartmoor National Park but now destroyed, this single stone row is of unknown length, but was recorded as being made up of 10 small stones sitting at an orientation of 135 degrees and at an altitude of 406 metres.  Whilst the row has been destroyed, the terminal cairn with a cist and a double circle of stones still remains.

Butterdon East.name: Butterdon East
Butterdon East.description: Butterdon East is a single stone row, comprising 3 large stones making up a length of 55 metres.

Mardon Down N.name: Mardon Down N
Mardon Down N.description: Listed as Cairn Circle on OS Map, this is a nicely-sited circle in good condition, overlooking the rolling hills of north Dartmoor. Both Mardon Down circles are along the ridge-line and offer splendid views in all directions.

Wistman's wood Settlement.name: Wistman's wood Settlement
Wistman's wood Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Beardown Cairn and Cist.name: Beardown Cairn and Cist
Beardown Cairn and Cist.description: Beardown Platform Cairn Circle and Cist can be found near the Lich Way, to the north of Beardown Tors, East of Lydford Tor, on the hillside above where the Lich Way drops down to cross the West Dart river.

Craze Lowman Mound.name: Craze Lowman Mound
Craze Lowman Mound.description: A prehistoric mound in Devon, possibly a flattened bowl barrow, up to 1m high and 15m in diameter. Cut in half by a road.

Archerton Settlement.name: Archerton Settlement
Archerton Settlement.description: Archerton Settlement is roughly oval in shape. It measures about 110m NNE-SSW by 90m (approximately 0.81 hectares in area) within a broad rubble wall or bank which is denuded and probably extensively robbed.

Chittaford Down cairn circle and cist.name: Chittaford Down cairn circle and cist
Chittaford Down cairn circle and cist.description: Chittaford Down cairn circle and cist has a diameter of 8.0m and a height of 0.6m, with seven stones of a peristalith protruding through the turf. There is a central cist oriented north west/south east consisting of two-side stones and two end-stones.

Whealam cist.name: Whealam cist
Whealam cist.description: The remains of this cist lie some 80m E of the Whealam streamworks at SX 61666985, on gently sloping ground 50m S of the newtake wall.

Rha cairn circle and cist.name: Rha cairn circle and cist
Rha cairn circle and cist.description: A little ovoid cairn circle and cist.

Harbourne Head Standing Stone.name: Harbourne Head Standing Stone
Harbourne Head Standing Stone.description: The Harbourne Head menhir is situated west of the head of the Harbourne stream. It is 2.40m in length and 1.0m by 0.3m at its base tapering to 0.3m by 0.15m.

Harbourne Head A.name: Harbourne Head A
Harbourne Head A.description: Two cairns on the summit of their hill. The North West one is 22.5 metres in diameter with a height of approximately 1.0 metre.

Hembury Fort.name: Hembury Fort
Hembury Fort.description: Neolithic Causewayed Enclosure and Iron Age Hillfort in Devon. All above-ground traces of the Causewayed Enclosure seem to have disappeared.

Stoke Rivers fort.name: Stoke Rivers fort
Stoke Rivers fort.description: Stoke Rivers [Beara] Camp is located in Devon.

Whitehorse Hill cist.name: Whitehorse Hill cist
Whitehorse Hill cist.description: Small Bronze age cist on Whitehorse Hill, Dartmoor Forest. Discovered in the early 21st century and scheduled in 2003. Due to its remote location it represented a rare example of an undisturbed cist on Dartmoor. It was excavated in August 2011.

Bellever Tor 9.name: Bellever Tor 9
Bellever Tor 9.description: A cist within the remains of an approximately 3m diameter retaining circle.  For more information see

Delamore House dolmen.name: Delamore House dolmen
Delamore House dolmen.description: I came across this modern dolmen by accident when someone told me about Delamore House near Ivybridge. I see they have an open art exhibition there at the moment, if you're looking for somewhere to visit in Devon or Cornwall.

Sittaford Stone Circle.name: Sittaford Stone Circle
Sittaford Stone Circle.description: Dave P writes: A new stone circle has been reported on Dartmoor according to the Devon Archaeological Society Newsletter (Jan 2014 No. 117).  It was discovered by Alan Endacott in 2007 but I have not seen any public mention of it until now.

Puddock's Well.name: Puddock's Well
Puddock's Well.description: Angie Lake and friend Peter Green, who instigated the search in Oct. 2010, visited this well on 22nd April 2015 as part of their investigations into the site of a possible major Celtic Sanctuary in the mid-Devon area around the 'nymet' villages.

Merrivale Menhir.name: Merrivale Menhir
Merrivale Menhir.description: A large Standing Stone making up part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon. The menhir is 42 metres south of the centre of the stone circle, and is 3.1 metres high. Several other small stones stand in the vicinity, and there are also the remains of several cairns and pits.

Shell Top South-West stone row.name: Shell Top South-West stone row
Shell Top South-West stone row.description: A 73.5m long single stone row including about 30 slabs most of which are fallen. A large recumbent slab at the northern (upper end) probably represents a fallen terminal pillar and a spread mound at the south is likely to be a cairn.

Holne Moor.name: Holne Moor
Holne Moor.description: Holne Moor Triple Stone Row in Devon, 150 m long. Most of the stones hardly show above the peat.  There is a fallen 3.4m longstone at the Western end.

Money Pit cairn.name: Money Pit cairn
Money Pit cairn.description: This site has often been referred to as a stone circle, but it is in fact the remains of a round barrow with a double retaining kerb circle with diameter of c.3m and interior cist. 2 partially destroyed and badly robbed stone rows descend form the circle at the NNW and the SSE.

Merrivale row 4.name: Merrivale row 4
Merrivale row 4.description: Merrivale single stone row 4, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon. A short row of 4 small stones next to the large standing stone. Although close to the menhir the row is clearly not aligned on it.

Hart Tor North prehistoric settlement.name: Hart Tor North prehistoric settlement
Hart Tor North prehistoric settlement.description: The settlement includes at least 50 round houses, several lengths of rubble walling and at least two cairns.

Hart Tor North ring cairn.name: Hart Tor North ring cairn
Hart Tor North ring cairn.description: A ring cairn surviving as a partial ring of close-set stones standing up to 0.75m high, surrounding a slightly raised internal area with a diameter of 7.5m.

Woolacombe Memorial.name: Woolacombe Memorial
Woolacombe Memorial.description: Modern Standing stone type memorial above the beach at Woolacombe, for the American soldiers of the second World War based in this area.

Damage Barton 3.name: Damage Barton 3
Damage Barton 3.description: Northernmost of three standing stones to the northeast of Mortehoe.

Damage Barton 2.name: Damage Barton 2
Damage Barton 2.description: Second of three standing stones to the northeast of Mortehoe.

Whitestone (Lee).name: Whitestone (Lee)
Whitestone (Lee).description: Spending a wet New Years afternoon exploring the top left corner of Devon, I noticed on my map some standing stones marked (unknown to me), one of which was near to a small road leading down to a cove at Lee Bay, so I went for a look.

Grey Wethers..name: Grey Wethers.
Grey Wethers..description: The walk to this double-ringed circle is long and tedious, but well worth the effort. Excavated in 1898 and restored in 1909, they contained charcoal bits throughout. Attention to detail during construction is obvious in that the circles stand almost exactly north-south of one another.

Longstone hill.name: Longstone hill
Longstone hill.description: Cairn and fallen standing stone in Devon

Fordsland Ledge Chambered cairn.name: Fordsland Ledge Chambered cairn
Fordsland Ledge Chambered cairn.description: Fordsland Ledge Chambered cairn is 12.2m by 13.9m in diameter, in the middle of the cairn are the stones of a ruined chamber.

Yes Tor cairns.name: Yes Tor cairns
Yes Tor cairns.description: Two cairns at the top of Yes Tor on Dartmoor, the western one is massive and now looks like a huge ring cairn (it's not).

Raddick Hill North.name: Raddick Hill North
Raddick Hill North.description: Raddick Hill North is a Bronze Age enclosed settlement sitting on the southern edge of a tin streamwork scarp. The settlement survives as a sub-circular enclosure with an entrance on its west side.

Three Barrows West prehistoric settlemen.name: Three Barrows West prehistoric settlement
Three Barrows West prehistoric settlemen.description: A dense concentration of prehistoric enclosures and round houses on the west facing slopes of the Erme Valley on Dartmoor.

Twitchen barrows.name: Twitchen barrows
Twitchen barrows.description: Two prehistoric round barrows are visible at the east end of the summit of Twitchen Ridge.

St Leonard's Well (Hartland).name: St Leonard's Well (Hartland)
St Leonard's Well (Hartland).description: St Leonard's Well, Newton Cross, Hartland, Devon. This is on the site of St Leonard's Chapel and there are still remnants of medieval stone windows built into the wall of the old cottage just up from the well.

Fernworthy.name: Fernworthy
Fernworthy.description: This is the overall sitepage for the Fernworthy collection of ceremonial sites. On the eastern upslopes of Dartmoor, just a couple of miles to the southwest of the lovely little old town of Chagford at the upper reaches of the South Teign River, is found the lovely Fernworthy Reservoir within the Fernworthy Forest plantation, now a popular nature reserve and outdoor recreation area. Within this forest at a place known as Froggymead can be found the Fernworthy collection of ancient prehistoric ceremonial sites, which consist of a stone circle, three stone rows or avenues with their associated terminal cairns, plus a few other cairns. Also within this forest can be found several ancient settlements consisting of ancient hut circles and other related structures.

White Ridge pound.name: White Ridge pound
White Ridge pound.description: Circular enclosure similar to its larger neighbour a couple of hundred metres to the north, although about half its size. Now identified as a ring cairn.

Fernworthy Cairn 4.name: Fernworthy Cairn 4
Fernworthy Cairn 4.description: The first monument to look for, which you might otherwise miss is cairn 4, found right at the corner of forest, trackway and open area.

Fernworthy Cairn N.name: Fernworthy Cairn N
Fernworthy Cairn N.description: The cairn at the northern terminus of the northern stone row was until fairly recently covered by the forest, but this has now been cleared. Its not much to look at, but clearly defines the northern end of the row.

Fernworthy Cairn SW.name: Fernworthy Cairn SW
Fernworthy Cairn SW.description: The northern terminus of the southwestern stone row 3 is a circular cairn about 8 metres in diameter with a surrounding cairn of small stones.

Fernworthy Cairn SE.name: Fernworthy Cairn SE
Fernworthy Cairn SE.description: The northern terminus of the southeastern stone row 2 is a circular cairn about 8 metres in diameter with a possible surrounding cairn of small stones.

Cairns East of White Tor.name: Cairns East of White Tor
Cairns East of White Tor.description: There is a group of four Cairns to the east of White Tor in the parish of Peter Tavy on Dartmoor, of which three are in very close proximity to each other.

Cairns North of Roos Tor.name: Cairns North of Roos Tor
Cairns North of Roos Tor.description: There are remains of a couple of cairns on the top of the raise, on the ridgetop about halfway between Roos Tor and Langstone Moor stone circle

Black Tor (Meavy).name: Black Tor (Meavy)
Black Tor (Meavy).description: Double Stone Row in Devon. The row measures 950 feet (289.43m) long and terminates at the north-east in a blocking stone. The position of the blocking stone indicates that the row was originally of the double type and that the northern stones have been buried by the adjacent field boundary.

Royal Hill Cairns (SX620721).name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX620721)
Royal Hill Cairns (SX620721).description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

Soussons Down Cairns.name: Soussons Down Cairns
Soussons Down Cairns.description: Four Bronze Age round barrows between 10 and 20 meters in diameter and 0.5 to 2.2 meters high. One barrow was excavated in 1902, finds included pottery and flints.

Hookney Tor Cairn.name: Hookney Tor Cairn
Hookney Tor Cairn.description: A tor cairn situated on Hookney Tor and forming part of a discrete cluster of mounds running along a prominent ridge. The cairn includes a rubble bank attached to the southern face of a rock outcrop.

Birch Tor Cairn.name: Birch Tor Cairn
Birch Tor Cairn.description: The remains of a large, flat-topped cairn lie on the ridge crest 230m N of Birch Tor. The spread, heather-covered mound measures 16m N to S by 18m and a maximum of 1.8m high on the W.

Chagford Common Cairn.name: Chagford Common Cairn
Chagford Common Cairn.description: A small round barrow 15 feet diameter by 1.5 feet high, situated

Hurston Ridge Settlement.name: Hurston Ridge Settlement
Hurston Ridge Settlement.description: The walls of an enclosed hut circle settlement and 3 Hut circles - SX 6733 8249, SX 6736 8251 and SX 6741 8257.

Royal Hill Cairns (SX621723).name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX621723)
Royal Hill Cairns (SX621723).description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

Royal Hill Cairns (SX621724).name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX621724)
Royal Hill Cairns (SX621724).description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

Royal Hill Cairns (SX618719).name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX618719)
Royal Hill Cairns (SX618719).description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

Bellever Tor 6.name: Bellever Tor 6
Bellever Tor 6.description: Jeremy Butler lists ten cairns/kists in the West to South of Bellever Tor. This one is number six in a field by the Cherrybrook River with many other Cairns/kists in the same field. They can be hard to find as the marsh grass is longer then the stones of all these monuments.

Bellever Tor Cairn one.name: Bellever Tor Cairn one
Bellever Tor Cairn one.description: A nicely formed cairn is found at the edge of the forest with a few surrounding kerbstones and a large capstone covering the remnants of a cist underneath.

Money Pit Cairns.name: Money Pit Cairns
Money Pit Cairns.description: Two mounds are visible in the vicinity of Grinsell's grid references. That at SX 68147384 is circular, measuring 4.5m. in diameter and 0.7m. high. Adjacent is an elongated mound measuring 11.5m. by 4.4m. and 0.7m. high.

Hembury Castle.name: Hembury Castle
Hembury Castle.description: Hembury Castle is a prehistoric hillfort near Buckfastleigh, not to be confused with the better known Hembury near Honiton in Devon.

Water hill cairn.name: Water hill cairn
Water hill cairn.description: A cairn on the top of Water hill, really great views.

Leather Tor.name: Leather Tor
Leather Tor.description: Situated on the southern slopes of Leather Tor, a Cairn and Cist, next to a track off of a minor road at Cross Gate near Burrator Reservoir.

Long Stone (East Worlington).name: Long Stone (East Worlington)
Long Stone (East Worlington).description: A precariously leaning 2.2 metre tall longstone in the parish of East Worlington, near to the village of Witheridge in north Devon

Stonehenge at Babbacombe Model Village.name: Stonehenge at Babbacombe Model Village
Stonehenge at Babbacombe Model Village.description: Babbacombe Model Village in Torquay has a model of Stonehenge which looks pretty accurate, bar the lack of crowds.

Ringmoor Down Cairn 4.name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 4
Ringmoor Down Cairn 4.description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, several varied cairns can be found. Cairn 4 is marked on the OS map as enclosure, about 100m southwest of the circle of stones, and is likely the remains of a fairly large ring cairn of 35 metres diameter.

Ringmoor Down Cairn 1.name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 1
Ringmoor Down Cairn 1.description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, several varied cairns can be found. The 10 metre diameter Cairn 1 is about 100m east of Brisworthy stone circle, and was excavated in 1909 with little found.

Yellowmead ring cairn.name: Yellowmead ring cairn
Yellowmead ring cairn.description: Remains of a ring cairn located ~200m from the main circles

Ringmoor Down Cairn 2.name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 2
Ringmoor Down Cairn 2.description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, several varied cairns can be found. The splendid 5m diameter cairn 2 is to be found about 3 or 400 metres to the northeast of Brisworthy stone circle, but out of sight over the hill.

Legis Tor Cairns.name: Legis Tor Cairns
Legis Tor Cairns.description: On the south facing slopes to the east of Legis Tor, uphill from the eastern part of the settlement, can be found the remains of two fairly small cisted cairns about 4 metres in diameter.

Trowlesworthy West enclosure.name: Trowlesworthy West enclosure
Trowlesworthy West enclosure.description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are fund a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

Trowlesworthy Tor settlement.name: Trowlesworthy Tor settlement
Trowlesworthy Tor settlement.description: On the western slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, well above the marshes surrounding Blacka Brook are the well spread out remains of a large settlement, consisting of more than half a dozen large enclosures and related hut circles.

Legis Tor Enclosures.name: Legis Tor Enclosures
Legis Tor Enclosures.description: On the southern slopes of Legis Tor, on the northen banks of the River Plym, are the remains of a substantial settlement, consisting of 4 main enclosures with almost 50 hut circles identified either in or between the encolsures.

Trowlesworthy Tor north settlement.name: Trowlesworthy Tor north settlement
Trowlesworthy Tor north settlement.description: On the north eastern slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, on the southern banks of the River Plym below Spanish Lake, are the much ruined remains of a settlement.

Shadyback Tor settlement.name: Shadyback Tor settlement
Shadyback Tor settlement.description: To the west of Trowlesworthy Warren farmhouse, on a high spur of land jutting into the river Plym, are the remains of a fairly large settlement, consisting of several enclosed pounds with their hut circles.

St Helen's Well (Croyde).name: St Helen's Well (Croyde)
St Helen's Well (Croyde).description: On 6th April 2013 I found this holy well tucked down a little side lane serving modern houses.  I knew it was somewhere in Cott Lane, Croyde, having read a news article on the history of the village in the local paper.  Despite growing up in Braunton, about 5 miles away, I hadn't previously heard of it, and I didn't spot it while walking up the lane.

Wind Hill.name: Wind Hill
Wind Hill.description: The earthwork on Wind Hill overlooks the valley of the East Lyn, with Lynmouth Bay on the north side Â– a good defensive position.  It is now owned by the National Trust, its eastern rampart a still imposing three metres high.

Horn's Cross.name: Horn's Cross
Horn's Cross.description: Horn's Cross stands 2 meters high on Holne Moor.   It can be quite difficult to reach in the summer through the dense bracken and in winter the ground is very boggy, but it is worth the trek as there are amazing views all around.

Blackslade Down Cairn and Cist.name: Blackslade Down Cairn and Cist
Blackslade Down Cairn and Cist.description: This ruined cairn and its reasonably intact cist lies in a shallow valley between Pil Tor and Wittaburrow on Dartmoor.  On the OS map this area is marked as 'Blackslade Down'.

Wittaburrow Cairn.name: Wittaburrow Cairn
Wittaburrow Cairn.description: This cairn high up on Wittaburrow hill is visible from some distance and I'd noticed it while walking to Tunhill Rocks.

Tunhill Rocks.name: Tunhill Rocks
Tunhill Rocks.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Foales Arrishes.name: Foales Arrishes
Foales Arrishes.description: Ancient settlement of eight large hut circles in Devon (Dartmoor). This site is actually easier to unravel when viewed from the top of Rippon Tor, to the ESE. When walking along the lower SE contours of the tors - the ridge above FoaleÂ’s Arrishes is fairly level, and Pil Tor is approx SSW of Top Tor - you are met with a jumble of light-coloured stones, and a profusion of bracken.

Shovel Down row 2.name: Shovel Down row 2
Shovel Down row 2.description: Double Stone Row between SX65958620 to SX65958603, making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

Smallacombe Rocks Settlement.name: Smallacombe Rocks Settlement
Smallacombe Rocks Settlement.description:
Smallacombe Rocks Settlement is situated almost due North of the popular Haytor Rocks on Dartmoor.  
The gigantic outcrops of granite that form Haytor Rocks lie near the B3387 from Bovey Tracey to Widecombe in the Moor and are visible from the south east coast at Teignmouth.  It isn't very peaceful, as holidaymakers, and locals alike, regularly visit this stunning scenic area with its panoramic views.

Black Hill Cairns.name: Black Hill Cairns
Black Hill Cairns.description: Cairn in Devon. Black Hill is a spur at the northern edge of the high ground of Haytor Down, below which the ground falls sharply away to the wooded valley of the River Bovey.  It is outside the land bounded by parallel reaves and may have been reserved for burial monuments as no huts have been found here.

Butterdon Hill Long Cairn.name: Butterdon Hill Long Cairn
Butterdon Hill Long Cairn.description: Distinct from the Butterdon Hill Cairns site - this long barrow is on the SE flank of Butterdon Hill, just north of the Cuckoo Ball burial chamber. It is marked on the OS map of Dartmoor, and although it is now little more than a low mound it is not too difficult to find. Walking uphill from Cuckoo Ball chamber it is just beside (to the N of) the third rough track encountered. There are some stones visible but little coherent structure.

Chagford Druid's Well.name: Chagford Druid's Well
Chagford Druid's Well.description: This is an odd site whose name is probably Victorian rather than ancient. The spring is enclosed in an unusual 'mini dolmen' structure.

Yellowmead cairn.name: Yellowmead cairn
Yellowmead cairn.description: This small Cairn is 38m from the centre of Yellowmead stone Circle. This can be easily missed but is worth hunting out as lt is a very small circle Cairn no more then 2 meters in diameter with five stone still standing.

Milber Down Camp.name: Milber Down Camp
Milber Down Camp.description: Hillfort with stock enclosure in Devon. It consists of three concentric enclosures: the innermost is 116 by 96 metres, the second and third are narrow strips 10 to 25 metres wide, each being defended by a large rampart and ditch.

Royal Albert Memorial Museum.name: Royal Albert Memorial Museum
Royal Albert Memorial Museum.description: Exeter and Devon's main museum - The Royal Albert Memorial Museum - set in an imposing old Victorian building in Queen Street, just off the main high street in Exeter's vibrant city centre, is a great place to while away a day and learn more about the history of the county.

Kent's Cavern.name: Kent's Cavern
Kent's Cavern.description: Paleolithic Cave in Devon. Kents Cavern is a cave system in Torquay, Devon, England. It is notable for its archaeological and geological features. The caves are a geological Site of Special Scientific Interest and a Scheduled Ancient Monument, and are open to the public.

Seaton Down Camp.name: Seaton Down Camp
Seaton Down Camp.description: An Iron Age hill fort consisting of an earthwork with a large linear rampart, it lies at the edge of the north east end of the down on a high promontory, and is approximately 125 metres (410 ft) above sea level.

Higher Mattocks Down stone.name: Higher Mattocks Down stone
Higher Mattocks Down stone.description: Fallen standing stone, 2.8 metres in length, in Devon

Libbett's Well.name: Libbett's Well
Libbett's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon. Libbett's Well initially took a bit of finding, but since we now have photos of the route to it, anyone interested can follow these for an easy walk to the site. The well is mentioned in detail in Terry Faull's 'Secrets of the Hidden Source - In Search of Devon's Ancient and Holy Wells'.

Vixen Tor.name: Vixen Tor
Vixen Tor.description: Bronze Age cairn and cist. The cairn mound measures 5.5 metres in diameter and stands up to 0.2 metres high. The cist lies within the cairn and survives as a stone lined pit, with its top protruding above the present ground surface.

Dumpdon Great Camp.name: Dumpdon Great Camp
Dumpdon Great Camp.description: An Iron Age hillfort located on a detached hill at the southern end of a steep-sided ridge of Upper Greensand between the River Otter and the Luppitt Brook. The flat topped and triangular shaped hillfort of 2.6 hectares was defended by two substantial ramparts and ditches on the northern side, controlling the only easy line of approach, and by single ramparts on the east and west sides.

Doda Well.name: Doda Well
Doda Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon. Doda Well at the west end of the small but very picturesque village of Coffinswell is presently nearly overgrown with greenery where it nestles by the roadside. Situated at the west end of the village, it could be an early medieval holy well.  The name is Anglo-Saxon in origin: a personal name.

Holemoor Well.name: Holemoor Well
Holemoor Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Roundy Park Cairn.name: Roundy Park Cairn
Roundy Park Cairn.description: Situated next to the prehistoric enclosure of Roundy Park, this is one of the largest Cists exposed from its Cairn on Dartmoor.  It lies on the west bank of the East Dart River, about 3/4 of a mile NW of Postbridge, where parking is easily available in the Dartmoor National Park car park (with visitor centre and toilets).  Postbridge's other attraction is its famous clapper bridge.

Denbury.name: Denbury
Denbury.description: Hillfort in Devon. With two close-set ramparts and a deep ditch on the east and south sides, the fort was built around 300-100BC. The Bronze Age barrows inside were there earlier, probably built 1,000 years or more before the fort.

West Anstey Barrows.name: West Anstey Barrows
West Anstey Barrows.description: There are two prominent round barrows on Anstey Common hilltop, about a hundred metres to the north of the ridge top road, and easily accessible from readily available parking places.

Shovel Down Cairn Row 4.name: Shovel Down Cairn Row 4
Shovel Down Cairn Row 4.description: At the top end of stone row 4 is a 7 metre diameter cairn with a central pit.

Cheriton Ridge ring cairn.name: Cheriton Ridge ring cairn
Cheriton Ridge ring cairn.description: This was a very pleasant surprise, as many cairns on Exmoor are little more than a patch of thicker undergrowth.   Approaching from the north, what looks like a stone (which I assumed must be a sheep) can clearly be seen down by the saddle of the ridge, with some darker heather around it. As approaching nearer to this, and it can be seen that it is indeed a stone, with a few other smaller stones standing nearby.

Modern Stone Circle near Kestor Rock.name: Modern Stone Circle near Kestor Rock
Modern Stone Circle near Kestor Rock.description: Modern Stone Circle in Devon. On private land near Kestor Rock. There is no public access however it is visible from the publicly accessible moor.

Roborough Down Earthworks.name: Roborough Down Earthworks
Roborough Down Earthworks.description: "The Earthworks" on Roborough Down, near Yelverton, are an archaeological puzzle.

Western White Barrow.name: Western White Barrow
Western White Barrow.description: Western White Barrow is a large cairn, 21m by 17.5 m and a maximum of 1.7 m high, and lies on the summit of a broad level hill at 480 m above OD. It has been badly mutilated by the construction of a two room building, with fireplace, 11.5 m by 4.7 m overall, within its mass, and its original form is conjectural. Petre's Cross (SX 66 NE 37) has been set up upon the cairn.

Green Hill - Stall Moor.name: Green Hill - Stall Moor
Green Hill - Stall Moor.description: This Stone Row is part of the

Hoaroak Hill.name: Hoaroak Hill
Hoaroak Hill.description: I couldnÂ’t find anything of this, in a very swampy area. There is a nice tree and a couple of very active springs here in this delightful place.

Cheriton Ridge 6.name: Cheriton Ridge 6
Cheriton Ridge 6.description: Off the edge of Cheriton Ridge on the western Hoaroak Water side, near to the Hoar Oak itself, can be found the remains of this stone setting.

Cheriton Ridge 1.name: Cheriton Ridge 1
Cheriton Ridge 1.description: Stone Setting reported in my Exmoor Archaeology book, but I found nothing for these.

Cheriton Ridge 3.name: Cheriton Ridge 3
Cheriton Ridge 3.description: Stone Setting reported in my Exmoor Archaeology book, but I found nothing for these.

Farley Water stones.name: Farley Water stones
Farley Water stones.description: Â“Standing StonesÂ” are marked on the OS map. I looked all around for some standing stones, but could find nothing, except perhaps some stones which were laying flat on the ground, or perhaps a couple of stumps, but there was nothing which obviously shouted standing stone to me.

Tottiford Reservoir.name: Tottiford Reservoir
Tottiford Reservoir.description: Stone circle and rows in Devon. Archaeologists have discovered the remains of a prehistoric complex, buried beneath a reservoir in southern England. Archaeologists observing are justifiably astonished at its existence.

Brent Tor.name: Brent Tor
Brent Tor.description: Hillfort in Devon. Brent Tor is a conical shaped hill rising to a height of 330 metres above sea level. The hill is prominent with in its local landscape and rises steeply about 50 metres from its surrounding landscape.

Down Tor cairn.name: Down Tor cairn
Down Tor cairn.description: About 50 metres to the northwest of the beautiful cairn circle, around the edge of the hillside, is the remains of another cairn, 14 metre diameter and more than a metre high. There are no signs of any kerb stones or structure within the cairn.

Narrator Brookhead Enclosure.name: Narrator Brookhead Enclosure
Narrator Brookhead Enclosure.description: This is an oval shaped enclosure, approximately 50m by 30m which is defined by large stone walls, which nowadays make up a fallen structure about 3 metres wide by up to a metre high. Many upright stones can be seen within the walled structure.

Narrator Brookhead Cairn.name: Narrator Brookhead Cairn
Narrator Brookhead Cairn.description: This is a big old cairn which lies in line with the Down Tor stone row, about 150 metres distant from its eastern end. The cairn is about 20 metres in diameter, and up to 2 metres high. It is mostly a pile of clear granite stones, but in places it looks like there may be some structure to parts of it.

Holne Ridge NE.name: Holne Ridge NE
Holne Ridge NE.description: A couple of hundred metres west from Horn's Cross, can be found Holne Ridge cairn 2 and its supposed double stone row. I didnÂ’t think I was going to be able to find this as the area itÂ’s in is all covered by fern and bracken, but it was quite obvious once I got near. The cairn is well formed, about 7 metres in diameter about a metre tall with the expected hollow in the top.

Holne Ridge 7.name: Holne Ridge 7
Holne Ridge 7.description: Several cairns of various types and sizes are to be found on the slopes of Holne Ridge, near to Horn's Cross above the O Brook valley south of Dartmeet. Eleven cairns are recorded in Butler Vol 4, but I shall describe here only those which I have seen. I have given the position for cairn 7, which is easy to find being nearest to Horn's Cross, and approximately in the middle of the group.

Castle Dyke (Devon).name: Castle Dyke (Devon)
Castle Dyke (Devon).description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Bush Down Settlement.name: Bush Down Settlement
Bush Down Settlement.description: Ancient Settlement in Devon. A superb set of Hut Circles, Rows and Cysts near Lettaford.

High Moorland Visitor Centre.name: High Moorland Visitor Centre
High Moorland Visitor Centre.description: The High Moorland Visitor Centre (now renamed the National Park Visitor Centre, Princetown) is an ideal place to start your visit to Dartmoor.  There is FREE admission to the Centre, where you will find extensive, modern, interpretative displays that provide wonderful insights to Dartmoor, its history, culture and wildlife, as well as a gallery with regularly changing exhibitions and a small auditorium where visitors are able to watch various short films about Dartmoor. There is also a prehistoric cist in the garden.

Whitewell Woods Well.name: Whitewell Woods Well
Whitewell Woods Well.description: Holy Well in Devon. This beautiful Well was built c.1360 by monks on the instruction of the Bishop John de Grandisson of Exeter Cathedral. It was not strictly a Holy Well, but supplied water to the Farm that supported the Bishop's Summer Palace in Bishopsteignton. One purpose was to provide for fish ponds!

Furzehill Common 5.name: Furzehill Common 5
Furzehill Common 5.description: This excellent stone setting is to be found well off of the steep eastern slopes of Furzehill Common ridge, overlooking the splendid Hoaroak Water valley, with fantastic views. I almost didnÂ’t come and look for this one as time was getting on, the hillside was in shadow, and when I got near, I saw that the hillside was covered in ferns. I am glad to say that I did go for a quick look, and eventually found the best stone setting I had seen all day.

Stidwell.name: Stidwell
Stidwell.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Ten Commandments Stone.name: Ten Commandments Stone
Ten Commandments Stone.description: Natural Stone / Erratic / Other Natural Feature in Devon

Down Tor circle.name: Down Tor circle
Down Tor circle.description: This has to be one of the most attractive megalithic features on Dartmoor. It is a ring-cairn attached to a 349m (1145-foot) stone row that is concave as it dips downward and then rises upward with the terrain as it approaches the circle. The ruined cairn within the 11m (36-foot) diameter ring is some 8.5m (28 feet) across. There are twenty-five small stones forming the circle, averaging 0.5m (1 foot 7 inches) in height.

Grimspound.name: Grimspound
Grimspound.description: The best known and most easily accessible ancient settlement on Dartmoor. Grimspound is a late Bronze Age settlement, in an excellent state of preservation. The name was first recorded by the Reverend Richard Polwhele in 1797 - it was probably derived from the Anglo Saxon god of war, Grim (more commonly known as Woden, or Odin).

Furzehill Common cairn.name: Furzehill Common cairn
Furzehill Common cairn.description: Near to the top of Furzehill Common ridge are the remains of a cairn near to many stones which may once have formed a stone setting.

Furzehill Common 2.name: Furzehill Common 2
Furzehill Common 2.description: Supposedly a stone setting of three stones in a row, two are marked on the OS map. I found one stone standing just over a foot high surrounded by couch grass. With a good hunt around, I found only one other stump of a stone nearby.

Furzehill Common 0.name: Furzehill Common 0
Furzehill Common 0.description: Having crossed to Furzehill Common from Warcombe, I found the nearby tumulus easily, and was initially fooled by a small stone standing nearby. However, a bit further up the slopes at the correct position is a decent stone, 2.5 to 3 feet tall standing proud.

Warcombe Water stone.name: Warcombe Water stone
Warcombe Water stone.description: On the promontory of dry, higher ground leading down from The Chains to Warcombe Water can be found a standing stone, about 2.5 by 1 foot in dimension.

Ilkerton Ridge stones.name: Ilkerton Ridge stones
Ilkerton Ridge stones.description: I initially found a single stone standing, about three feet tall, but in a hollow amongst the dense heather, a few hundred metres south of the two obvious barrows.

Ilkerton Ridge Barrows.name: Ilkerton Ridge Barrows
Ilkerton Ridge Barrows.description: Several barrows and cairns are to be found on the crest of Ilkerton Ridge, one or two quite large and in very good condition, some of them very small and deteriorated.

Furzehill Common Barrow.name: Furzehill Common Barrow
Furzehill Common Barrow.description: On the western slopes of Furzehill Common, having crossed from Warcombe, I found this tumulus easily, which is fairly large and prominent on the slopes down the side of the ridge.

St Boniface's Well (Crediton).name: St Boniface's Well (Crediton)
St Boniface's Well (Crediton).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Archerton Newtake Cist.name: Archerton Newtake Cist
Archerton Newtake Cist.description: This large granite stone sits in a field to the southwest of the track leading NW up the East Dart River valley from Postbridge (on the river's west bank).  It is in one of the first sloping fields on the left and unmissable.  The far side (NW edge) of the field is bordered by trees.  (Coming back down the valley towards the main road, in the first view of it on your right, it appears to lie on the brow of the hill.)

Broadun Settlement.name: Broadun Settlement
Broadun Settlement.description: Ancient Settlement in Devon. This huge walled enclosure lies on the south east facing slope of Broad Down, commanding excellent views down the valley of the East Dart River towards Postbridge.  As you walk up the river valley towards it the hill dominates the view ahead.  The site isn't easy to pick out because it is so large.  Several ruined hut circles remain.

Broadun Ring.name: Broadun Ring
Broadun Ring.description: If you've read the notes on Broadun settlement's site page you'll know that Broadun Ring is just a bit further to the North around the same contour of Broad Down hill, overlooking the valley of the East Dart River, which heads north to south just there, before swinging towards SE as it passes Roundy Park.

Ladywell (Pilton).name: Ladywell (Pilton)
Ladywell (Pilton).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

Cut Hill Stone Row.name: Cut Hill Stone Row
Cut Hill Stone Row.description: Stone Row in Devon. Cut Hill, 603m high, is no ordinary hill, being one of only five Dartmoor points above 600m in altitude. To reach it requires a walk of about two hours from whatever direction. The hill has no rocky outcrops breaking its surface, but has a smooth domed shape. It is impressive and powerful, especially when approaching from the east, up the East Dart River. Its western flanks form the watershed of the River Tavy.

Buttern Hill settlement.name: Buttern Hill settlement
Buttern Hill settlement.description: The slopes of Buttern Hill are covered in the remains of ancient settlement, with many reaves and hut circles to be found dotted all over the hillside, particularly the north eastern slopes which seem to be the centre of the settlement.

Scorhill Cairn and Rows.name: Scorhill Cairn and Rows
Scorhill Cairn and Rows.description: One or two hundred metres south of Scorhill stone circle, below the leat, can be found the remains of a cairn, with remnants of a double stone row running downhill from it towards the river Teign.

Newton Abbot Museum.name: Newton Abbot Museum
Newton Abbot Museum.description: Newton Abbot Museum is situated in the centre of the town with some limited parking close by.  (Several other car parks in town centre.) There are steps leading to the entrance, but according to the website there is disabled access, toilets and a small shop.

Lakehead Hill Cairn 8.name: Lakehead Hill Cairn 8
Lakehead Hill Cairn 8.description: Taking Butlers reference number for this cist (cairn) between Lakehead Hill and Bellever Tor - as he groups it with 'Cairns and Stone Rows on Lakehead Hill' - it is posted here as 'Lakehead Hill Cairn 8'.

Lakehead Hill South Hut Circle.name: Lakehead Hill South Hut Circle
Lakehead Hill South Hut Circle.description: We visited this hut circle in September 2009.  It is just north of the 'Lichway' on the green and white map 'Prehistoric Features on Lakehead Hill' on this website:

Lakehead Hill 6.name: Lakehead Hill 6
Lakehead Hill 6.description: One of two adjacent cairn circles,

Bellever Tor N Settlement.name: Bellever Tor N Settlement
Bellever Tor N Settlement.description: This settlement lies on the northern slopes of Bellever Tor, and is described as a 'rosette' type of development by Butler in his 'Dartmoor Atlas of Antiquities' [Vol.2 - The North].

Lowton Brook West Settlement.name: Lowton Brook West Settlement
Lowton Brook West Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Hound Tor Ring Cairn.name: Hound Tor Ring Cairn
Hound Tor Ring Cairn.description: Hound Tor Ring Cairn, Dartmoor, Devon, is a ring cairn (Cairn Circle) 6.5 metres in diameter with an outer incomplete set of granite kerb stones. In the center of the cairn is a cist.

Whiteworks Cairn Circle.name: Whiteworks Cairn Circle
Whiteworks Cairn Circle.description: A Cairn Circle on an east facing moorland slope close to Whiteworks and Foxtor Mires, c.6 metres diameter and 0.6 metres high surrounded by upright slabs.

Bampfylde Hill Barrows.name: Bampfylde Hill Barrows
Bampfylde Hill Barrows.description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon. Angie Lake writes: On a visit to

Langridge Wood Cist.name: Langridge Wood Cist
Langridge Wood Cist.description: Cist in Devon. This Bronze Age cist is one of only seven to have been documented on Exmoor, only two of which survive.

Furzehill Common Standing Stone.name: Furzehill Common Standing Stone
Furzehill Common Standing Stone.description: This stone was until recently standing about 30 inches tall, but is now broken and laying sadly on the ground near some modern fencing and field boundaries. It is situated at the northeastern edge of Furzehill Common, above the very deep, steep sided Hoaroak Water valley.

Bellever Tor NE Settlement.name: Bellever Tor NE Settlement
Bellever Tor NE Settlement.description: Ancient Settlement in Devon. The nearest proper road is a couple of miles away. The toilet is an energetic yomp down a steep slope and through the conifers. When it rains Â– and here on Dartmoor it really does pelt down Â– the only shelter is project supervisor Simon Hughes's old VW Golf. "It's started to smell like a dead dog," he says with a big grin.

Harford settlement.name: Harford settlement
Harford settlement.description: Remains of an ancient settlement on Harford moor, southern Dartmoor. Many hut circles are to be found, several of them in a very good state of preservation.

Watchet Hill Cairn.name: Watchet Hill Cairn
Watchet Hill Cairn.description: Bronze Age cairn on the summit of Watchet Hill, oval mound is  0.8 metres high and measures 16.6 metres by 13.8 metres.

Sittaford Tor pound.name: Sittaford Tor pound
Sittaford Tor pound.description: This enigmatic monument consists of an oval shaped enclosure, about 50 metres east west by 40 metres north to south, defined by embanked rubble walls, up to a metre high and spread to a couple of metres in width.

Datuidoc's Stone.name: Datuidoc's Stone
Datuidoc's Stone.description: Early Christian Sculptured Stone in Devon

Yar Tor Prehistoric Homestead.name: Yar Tor Prehistoric Homestead
Yar Tor Prehistoric Homestead.description: This intriguing ruin lies just to the right of the road going down the very steep Dartmeet Hill below the summit of Yar Tor, when travelling towards Dartmeet from Poundsgate.  It is easier to see when the bracken dies down, but some of the remaining stones are quite prominent all year round.  There is a handy layby on the left of the road going downhill, which is easy enough to pull out of later (ample views of oncoming traffic on this very steep gradient.)  Then all you need to do is cross over and take a short walk across fairly even ground to the site.

Corndon Down Cairns.name: Corndon Down Cairns
Corndon Down Cairns.description: There are four cairns on Corndon Down.  I visited these to photograph them for the Megalithic Portal on Sunday 3rd May 2009, and on this late Spring afternoon, with the sun shining and a strong breeze blowing, it was really a 'superb' ambience, but this might not be so in bad weather!<

Ringmoor Down Cairn 3.name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 3
Ringmoor Down Cairn 3.description: High on Ringmoor are several very worn cairns and this kerbed stone cairn. It has probably been added to but it is a nice find on the featureless moorland.

Soussons Common.name: Soussons Common
Soussons Common.description: Often referred to as a stone circle, the circle of twenty-two surviving stones are actually the kerb of a round cairn, now destroyed.  In the centre lies a badly damaged burial cist.

Cosdon Hill cairn 9.name: Cosdon Hill cairn 9
Cosdon Hill cairn 9.description: This cairn on the north western slopes of Cosdon Hill is marked on the DEFRA Magic Map, and it has been suggested that perhaps I had found this when I thought I had found a stone circle. So, the first thing to do is to find and identify this cairn.

Sticklepath stone circle.name: Sticklepath stone circle
Sticklepath stone circle.description: Sticklepath stone circle was once well known on the northern slopes of Cosdon Hill, to the south of the village of Sticklepath. The stones were said to dance to the sound of South Tawton church bells.

Dolbury Hillfort.name: Dolbury Hillfort
Dolbury Hillfort.description: Dolbury Hillfort sits on a volcanic hill overlooking the National Trust property of Killerton House. Occupied 400BC-43AD.

Headless Cross (Moretonhampstead).name: Headless Cross (Moretonhampstead)
Headless Cross (Moretonhampstead).description: Modern Stone Circle / Monolith in Devon

The Giant's Grave Mardon Down.name: The Giant's Grave Mardon Down
The Giant's Grave Mardon Down.description: A 20 metre diameter cairn at the summit of Mardon Down in Devon

Mardon Down Ring Cairn.name: Mardon Down Ring Cairn
Mardon Down Ring Cairn.description: Ring Cairn on the summit ridge of Mardon Down in Devon.

Mardon Down Cairn 1.name: Mardon Down Cairn 1
Mardon Down Cairn 1.description: Just south of Mardon Down stone circle is what at first looks like a pile of large stones, but upon investigation is the remains of a cairn with much of the remains of a circle of surrounding stones, and with four large blocks at its southern side, and a large slab just on the outside, probably once the capstone to an internal cist.

Mardon Down Cairn 3.name: Mardon Down Cairn 3
Mardon Down Cairn 3.description: Just south of the Giant's Grave at the top of Mardon Down, is a smaller but much clearer cairn, about 10m diameter and still with some semblance of a retaining circle of stones.

Lade Hill Brook Beehive Hut.name: Lade Hill Brook Beehive Hut
Lade Hill Brook Beehive Hut.description: This beehive hut is situated beside Lade Hill Brook, which runs into the East Dart river just near a very sharp hairpin bend in its flow south. It is mentioned in Butlers 'Dartmoor Atlas of Antiquities, Vol.2 - The North'.  He shows a photograph of it next to map 34 in this series.

Berry Castle (Devon).name: Berry Castle (Devon)
Berry Castle (Devon).description: Berry Castle is a very small hillfort, almost rectangular in shape. All that remains is a shallow ditch and rampart in the middle of a cow field.

Witheridge Moor Barrows.name: Witheridge Moor Barrows
Witheridge Moor Barrows.description: There are three barrows on Witheridge Moor. The moorland was occupied in the bronze age. There are reports that there are several fallen standing stones situated near the eastern most barrow.

Whittenknowles Rocks.name: Whittenknowles Rocks
Whittenknowles Rocks.description: To the west of the Drizzlecombe sites, on a southern facing hillside, can be found the remains of the very large Whittenknowles Rocks ancient settlement.

Gutter Tor north.name: Gutter Tor north
Gutter Tor north.description: On the northern slopes of Gutter Tor can be found several cairns, some with cists within them, in various states of repair.

Seven Lords' Lands.name: Seven Lords' Lands
Seven Lords' Lands.description: Cairn-circle in Devon. Circle diameter: 33 feet. Shown as a cairn on the OS Map, this well-preserved cairn is easily accessible from the nearby road. It is disguised by the surrounding gorse and bracken, but only six stones are missing from the close-set kerb of stones. A field wall curves slightly in order to avoid the cairn.

Marwell St. Mary's Well.name: Marwell St. Mary's Well
Marwell St. Mary's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Hatherleigh St. John's Well.name: Hatherleigh St. John's Well
Hatherleigh St. John's Well.description: This is a delightful brick well house with a wooden door found across the common. The well was used by Tavistock abbey, but no properties are noted for it.

St. Rumon's well.name: St. Rumon's well
St. Rumon's well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

St. Urith's well.name: St. Urith's well
St. Urith's well.description: Holy Well in Devon. Possibly the most interesting of sites as it is associated with the 6th century Celtic Saint Urith who was martyred when the villages cut her head off with a scythe! Her shrine was in the church but lost at the reformation.

Holy Well (Tawstock).name: Holy Well (Tawstock)
Holy Well (Tawstock).description: Holy Well in Devon. One of the best and certainly largest holy wells in the county. I knew nothing of it when I looked for it and was surprised by the size!

Warcombe Water row.name: Warcombe Water row
Warcombe Water row.description: Stone Row on Exmoor. During spring 2006 burning of heather moorland near Ilkerton Ridge revealed a long line of standing stones stretching for some 70 metres. The row was discovered by Celia Haddon, a long time Megalithic Portal contributor. She reported the site to the Exmoor National Park archaeologist.

Trout Hill 4.name: Trout Hill 4
Trout Hill 4.description: Standing Stones in Devon. During 2006 a previously unrecorded stone setting was identified on Trout Hill. The site lies in an area already rich in stone settings, and was surveyed during 2007 by staff of the Universities of Leicester and Bristol. Stone settings are assumed to date from the Late Neolithic or Early Bronze Age (around 4500-3500 years ago) and seem to be unique to

Chapman Barrows Quincunx.name: Chapman Barrows Quincunx
Chapman Barrows Quincunx.description: Hoping to find my first complete and unadulterated Exmoor Quincunx (a setting of 5 stones arranged as a square with one in the middle, rather like the spots on the five side of a dice), this was the aim for my day out on the moor, and had entailed a 6.9 km walk across very boggy and marshy moorland to get to it.

Woodbarrow (Exmoor).name: Woodbarrow (Exmoor)
Woodbarrow (Exmoor).description: This is another large round barrow high up on Exmoor which is still in a good condition, although a very well used trackway runs past it just to its eastern side.

Longstone Barrow.name: Longstone Barrow
Longstone Barrow.description: This large round barrow is still in a very fine condition, with the ditch around it almost like a moat and full of water on a damp March day. As usual it has been dug into from the top, and this is a big pond today. It is one of the larger barrows on Exmoor, measuring about 30 metres diameter and nearly 3 metres high.

Chapman Down Barrow.name: Chapman Down Barrow
Chapman Down Barrow.description: There is a large round barrow on the southeastern slopes of  Chapman Down, which has a large slice cut through to the middle, rather than the usual hole in the top. Other than that, it is still in a very fine condition, with remains of a ditch around.

Jacob's Well (Jacobstow).name: Jacob's Well (Jacobstow)
Jacob's Well (Jacobstow).description: This well is found just over a stile in an area of marshy ground. The holy well is very overgrown but was believed to be one of a series of ancient sites adopted by pilgrims on the road to the shrine of St. James of Compostella.

Drizzlecombe Cist 6.name: Drizzlecombe Cist 6
Drizzlecombe Cist 6.description: About halfway between the cairn at the top of stone row 1, and the massive GiantÂ’s Basin cairn can be seen what at first looks like a little pile of large stones. Closer inspection shows this to be a collapsed cist, but with no signs of a surrounding cairn.

Drizzlecombe menhir 3.name: Drizzlecombe menhir 3
Drizzlecombe menhir 3.description: Terminal longstone at the southwestern (downhill) end of the Drizzlecombe stone row 3, and as for row 1, the stone is in line with the row, and not a blocker across it.

Drizzlecombe menhir 1.name: Drizzlecombe menhir 1
Drizzlecombe menhir 1.description: Part of the magnificent Drizzlecombe complex of southwest Dartmoor, this is a fantastic 3+ metre tall triangular shaped slab standing erect at the downhill end of the Drizzlecombe stone row A, which runs away uphill towards the northeast from it.

White Tor (Peter Tavy).name: White Tor (Peter Tavy)
White Tor (Peter Tavy).description: White Tor in the Parish of Peter Tavy is a very conspicuous hill on the western edge of Dartmoor, and slopes quite steeply on all sides. The top of the hill has a double concentric oval stone wall fortified structure, and many cairns, huts and other structures within it.

Langstone Moor stone row.name: Langstone Moor stone row
Langstone Moor stone row.description: Running off to the north from the Langstone is the remains of a stone row, which can be followed for about 100 metres before it runs out, but there is nothing to suggest that this was the original end.

Bow Henge.name: Bow Henge
Bow Henge.description: Bow Henge was discovered as crop-marks by the present Devon County Archaeologist Frances Griffith in 1984 whilst flying over Devon with Dickie Dougan (now deceased) as a part of an aerial archaeology exercise.

Ugborough Parish Church Prehistoric Eart.name: Ugborough Parish Church Prehistoric Earthwork
Ugborough Parish Church Prehistoric Eart.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

Shaugh Moor Cairns.name: Shaugh Moor Cairns
Shaugh Moor Cairns.description: On the moorland near to the Shaugh Moor Stone Row, in amongst the waste tips from the china clay works, are several cairns to be found, many in very poor condition.

Shaugh Moor Settlement.name: Shaugh Moor Settlement
Shaugh Moor Settlement.description: Several hut circles in various states of repair can be found just uphill from the Shaugh Moor stone row and cairn, one being very close to the cairn circle. At one place, there is a row of three fairly complete circles. A bit further uphill, there is one very good and almost complete hut circle, with evidence of an internal partition wall.

Sourton Green Saxon Cross.name: Sourton Green Saxon Cross
Sourton Green Saxon Cross.description: One and three quarter metre tall stone cross shaft standing on the village green opposite the bizarre Highwayman Inn. The granite stone has been identified as an early Christian, Saxon relic, and it has Os and Xs engraved onto two of its faces.

Roos Tor north west.name: Roos Tor north west
Roos Tor north west.description: Here on the western facing slopes of Roos Tor above Godsworthy are the remains of one of DartmoorÂ’s largest ancient settlements, with more than seventy huts to be found.

Cox Tor north east.name: Cox Tor north east
Cox Tor north east.description: Here are the remains of an ancient settlement, on the northeast facing slopes of Cox Tor above Godsworthy. The settlement consists of five enclosures and about 25 huts, which are largely in a fairly poor state of repair after the tinners have had their way, and with stone being taken for construction of the nearby farms and field walls.

Langstone Moor settlement.name: Langstone Moor settlement
Langstone Moor settlement.description: Here are the remains of a large ancient settlement, on the south facing slopes of Langstone moor above the Walkham valley. The settlement consists of at least seven enclosures and more than 50 huts, which are largely in a fairly good state of repair. This settlement had incomplete excavations here by the Dartmoor Exploration Committee in 1894, which were curtailed early due to bad weather.

Langstone Moor row 2.name: Langstone Moor row 2
Langstone Moor row 2.description: Running roughly parallel to the Langstone Moor stone row, less than 100 metres to the west, is an embanked structure, which is possibly an ancient reave, a boundary work, or outer defence for the White Tor fort. On the western side of this embankment runs a very regular line of evenly spaced slabs, which was possibly once another stone row, which was incorporated into the later structure. It is not certain.

The Langstone.name: The Langstone
The Langstone.description: This is a lovely menhir nearly 3 metres tall, standing beside the Lich Way on open ground in a saddle between the many local highpoints of the moor. It was re-erected from a fallen position in its original socket hole, in 1893 by the Dartmoor Exploration Committee.

Langstone Moor circle.name: Langstone Moor circle
Langstone Moor circle.description: What a lovely circle this must have been before it was largely destroyed as target practice during World War 2. It is superbly situated on a flattish bit of land high above the Walkham valley, seemingly equidistant from the three great tors overlooking the site, these being Great Mis Tor, Roos Tor and White Tor.

Belstone Ring Cross.name: Belstone Ring Cross
Belstone Ring Cross.description: The Belstone Ring Cross stands on a granite plinth inside the parish church at Belstone village on the north slopes of Dartmoor.  At eye-level, on the wall beside it, is a board with an account of its history and a helpful diagram to enable the viewer to distinguish the shape of the original carvings.

Torquay Museum.name: Torquay Museum
Torquay Museum.description: Museum in Devon.  Their archaeology gallery covers the prehistory of the local area including Kents Cavern

Hoccombe Hill (E).name: Hoccombe Hill (E)
Hoccombe Hill (E).description: In the deepest depths of Exmoor, several kilometres to the northeast of Brendon Two Gates, can be found the remains of this stone setting. It is well down the valleyside, on a sort of diagonal flatter bit, to the south of the main trackway along Hoccombe Hill.

Cadbury Castle (Devon).name: Cadbury Castle (Devon)
Cadbury Castle (Devon).description: Hillfort in Devon. Cadbury Castle is an early Iron Age earthwork Fort. Approximately 830ft (250m) above sea-level with views over the Exe valley.

Brendon Two Gates (W).name: Brendon Two Gates (W)
Brendon Two Gates (W).description: Out on the open moorland to the north of Brendon Two Gates, and to the east of the road, can be found the remains of this stone setting. What I found (March 2007) was three stones in a row, roughly in a NW to SE direction, with the stones each set about 7 metres apart.

Sidbury Castle.name: Sidbury Castle
Sidbury Castle.description: Sidbury Castle is a substantial Iron Age Hill fort near Sidbury in Devon. It occupies a large hilltop overlooking the town and the River Sid at approx 185 Metres above Sea Level.

Drizzlecombe cairn 1..name: Drizzlecombe cairn 1.
Drizzlecombe cairn 1..description: This cairn is at the upper end of Drizzlecombe stone row 1 (or A), and is about 7 metres in diameter, and 0.7 metres in height. As usual, it has been dug into at the middle.

Drizzlecombe cist 21.name: Drizzlecombe cist 21
Drizzlecombe cist 21.description: A bit further up the Drizzlecombe valley from the main sites, on the eastern side of the stream, can be found cist 21.

Drizzlecombe cist 22.name: Drizzlecombe cist 22
Drizzlecombe cist 22.description: To the south of the main Drizzlecombe sites can be found this cairn with cist. There is not much of the cairn surviving, but a good cist exists, standing proud of the ground.

Drizzlecombe cairn 14.name: Drizzlecombe cairn 14
Drizzlecombe cairn 14.description: Kerbed cairn ring making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon.

Drizzlecombe menhir 2.name: Drizzlecombe menhir 2
Drizzlecombe menhir 2.description: This is a splendid 4.2 metre tall stone standing up and across the downhill end of the Drizzlecombe stone row C, as a blocker. The stone row runs away uphill towards the northeast from it to its cairn at the top.

Drizzlecombe stone 4.name: Drizzlecombe stone 4
