Drizzlecombe stone 4.description: This stone slab is to be found a hundred metres or so across the Drizzlecombe moorland to the northwest of menhir 1. It stands just over a metre tall, 0.6 m wide and 0.2 m thick.

Clannon Ball.name: Clannon Ball
Clannon Ball.description: Out on the very blowy moorland to the northwest of Brendon Two Gates, on the slopes above the upper Farley water valley, can be found the remains of this stone setting. I found three stones in a pretty regular triangle shape, but there was possibly once many more stones to be found here.

Pig Hill (S).name: Pig Hill (S)
Pig Hill (S).description: The southern Pig Hill Stone Setting is a nice Exmoor stone setting to visit, although it is not that easy to find. It is on a west facing slope above Farley Water, about 400 metres west of the B.3223 road.

Pig Hill (N).name: Pig Hill (N)
Pig Hill (N).description: Despite being very close to the B.3223 road north of Brendon Two Gates, I found this stone setting very hard to find due to heather and bracken covering the stones.

West Anstey Long Stone.name: West Anstey Long Stone
West Anstey Long Stone.description: Despite being just a couple of hundred metres to the north of the ridge top road, and easily reached along bridleways from a good parking area, this stone is not the easiest to find, as it cannot be seen from the road, or indeed from anywhere to the south until you are quite close, as it lies well below the ridge top.

St Nectan's Well (Welcombe).name: St Nectan's Well (Welcombe)
St Nectan's Well (Welcombe).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Fitz's Well.name: Fitz's Well
Fitz's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Fice's Well.name: Fice's Well
Fice's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Stalldon Row.name: Stalldon Row
Stalldon Row.description: This magnificent stone row stretches for over 500 metres in a north to south direction, mostly up the southern slopes of Stalldon Barrow hill, but with its northerly end just over the top of hill, and starting to wander back down the northern hillside.

St Clare's Well.name: St Clare's Well
St Clare's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

St Gudula's Well.name: St Gudula's Well
St Gudula's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

St Peter's Well (Bradworthy).name: St Peter's Well (Bradworthy)
St Peter's Well (Bradworthy).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

Holy Well (Broadclyst).name: Holy Well (Broadclyst)
Holy Well (Broadclyst).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

Coverney Well.name: Coverney Well
Coverney Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

Holy Well (Belstone).name: Holy Well (Belstone)
Holy Well (Belstone).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Ladywell (Abbotskerswell).name: Ladywell (Abbotskerswell)
Ladywell (Abbotskerswell).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Lady Well (Sticklepath).name: Lady Well (Sticklepath)
Lady Well (Sticklepath).description: This well is located beside the old A30 road at the western edge of Sticklepath village. It is very close to a turnoff to the hamlet of Skaigh.

St Mary's Well (Bovey Tracey).name: St Mary's Well (Bovey Tracey)
St Mary's Well (Bovey Tracey).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

ChildeÂ’s Tomb.name: ChildeÂ’s Tomb
ChildeÂ’s Tomb.description: To the north of Fox Tor, and on the southern edge of the legendary Foxtor Mire can be found the remains of ChildeÂ’s Tomb, named after the legend of Childe the Hunter, who supposedly froze to death here in a snowstorm in the 12th century. The hunter had left his considerable lands to whoever found and recovered his body for a proper burial, and the monks of Tavistock completed this task and built the cross on top of the ancient grave as a memorial to him.

Upper Erme Row.name: Upper Erme Row
Upper Erme Row.description: This is the longest ancient stone row in Britain, and possibly the world, at just over 3.3 kilometres in length, stretching from the Kiss-in-the-Ring stone circle at the south, northwards along the upper Erme valley and up to a cairn near the top of Green Hill at the north. The southern end is at position SX63526446, the north end at SX63666779.

Stall Moor circle.name: Stall Moor circle
Stall Moor circle.description: At the southern end of the longest ancient stone row in Britain, and possibly the world, can be found the Kiss-in-the-Ring stone circle, miles away from any modern habitation, and a long desolate walk from anywhere.

Ranny Brookhead Cist.name: Ranny Brookhead Cist
Ranny Brookhead Cist.description: The Ranny Brookhead cist is in the middle of a featureless bit of moor near the bottom of the dip between Stall Moor and Stalldown Barrow, in amongst the damp ground surrounding the Ranny Brook.

Royal Hill Cairns.name: Royal Hill Cairns
Royal Hill Cairns.description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown. Perhaps the best preserved is cairn 3 at SX620721 which has an almost complete kerb circle, but I did not visit that cairn on my visit.

Crock of Gold.name: Crock of Gold
Crock of Gold.description: The Crock of Gold is a fine cairn and cist which can be found just to the south of the track which runs east from Princetown as part of the Dartmoor way, and is named no doubt after a lucky find here by somebody in the past.

Erme Pound.name: Erme Pound
Erme Pound.description: This is an excellently preserved ancient village on the eastern flanks of the upper Erme valley, one of the largest on Dartmoor, with superb walls around the outside, with at least one entry into it, from near the stream at the north.

Hook Lake Settlement.name: Hook Lake Settlement
Hook Lake Settlement.description: Well preserved ancient settlement on the eastern flanks of the Erme valley, consisting of two large walled enclosures, the one to the north a circular shape, with a sort of triangular one to the south. Each enclosure contains several huts.

Blatchford Brook Foot Settlement.name: Blatchford Brook Foot Settlement
Blatchford Brook Foot Settlement.description: Well preserved ancient settlement on the eastern flanks of the Erme valley, on a bend in the river where the Blatchford Brook joins from the west.

Dry Lake North Settlement.name: Dry Lake North Settlement
Dry Lake North Settlement.description: Fairly well preserved ancient settlement on the eastern flanks of the Erme valley, consisting of several large walled enclosures, each containing several huts.

The Heath Stone.name: The Heath Stone
The Heath Stone.description: The Heath Stone can be found not far from the road on the way to Fernworthy Reservoir, on the open moor just before you get to the forest.

GrimÂ’s Grave.name: GrimÂ’s Grave
GrimÂ’s Grave.description: What a lovely find GrimÂ’s Grave is, miles from anywhere across the middle of Southern Dartmoor, and well worth a visit.

Langcombe Brook 4.name: Langcombe Brook 4
Langcombe Brook 4.description: Several cairns and kists, and some remains of ancient settlement are to be found along the Langcombe Brook, which feeds into the river Plym just above the Drizzlecombe complex. Many of these can be found fairly easily along the sides of the brook, but itÂ’s a long walk from anywhere in remote southern Dartmoor.

The Tolmen Stone (Dartmoor).name: The Tolmen Stone (Dartmoor)
The Tolmen Stone (Dartmoor).description: The Tolmen Stone is a large boulder that lies near to the bank of the North Teign river. It has a large hole that perforates through the rock and was formed by river friction erosion. The hole is large enough for a normal sized adult to pass through and is estimated to have a diameter of 1.03m. There are also three other partially worn basins on the boulder.

Burridge Ancient Settlement.name: Burridge Ancient Settlement
Burridge Ancient Settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon. This is an ancient settlement or camp, not to be confused with Burridge Camp near Banstable, Devon. Presumably pre-Roman, it is ringed by still-substantial double banks and a ditch forming a central area about 500 metres accross. There are what appear to be entrances on the Western and Eastern sides.

Saxon Well.name: Saxon Well
Saxon Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Kraps Ring.name: Kraps Ring
Kraps Ring.description: Located in an open area within the Bellever Plantation on the north facing slope of Lakehead Hill, lies this rather unfortunatly named Bronze Age enclosure. Surrounded by a wall up to 2m in width and probably originally 1m in height, the settlement is c 60m diameter and contains the remains of at least 11 huts (though a plan of 1891 indicates up to 15 huts). Interestingly the remains of a much larger hut (6m diameter), lies outside the settlement, some 35m uphill to the southwest.

Lakehead Hill Cairn 7.name: Lakehead Hill Cairn 7
Lakehead Hill Cairn 7.description: Cairn in Devon. This now heavilly disturbed cairn lies within a small clearing in the Bellever Plantation, not far from the forest track. The cairn measures c. 20m diameter, though the disturbance has spread much of the original material. Two sides of a large central cist have been exposed, and the tops of a number of earthfast stones around the northern edge maybe all that remains of an outer ring.

St. Brannoc's Holy Well (Braunton).name: St. Brannoc's Holy Well (Braunton)
St. Brannoc's Holy Well (Braunton).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Yar Tor Summit.name: Yar Tor Summit
Yar Tor Summit.description: Cairn on Dartmoor, Devon. A cairn, c.18m in diameter, built over the highest rocks of the Tor. Its stones have been arranged to form an elaborate shelter. The cairn's pre-historicity may be doubtful. It may be a modern construction built for shelter purposes.

Ouldsbroom Cross.name: Ouldsbroom Cross
Ouldsbroom Cross.description: Ancient Cross in Devon. Both William Crossing and Harry Starkey refer to this cross as 'Ouldsbroom Cross', though it often takes its name from a nearby house called 'Ollsbrim' on the Ordnance Survey map.

Sherwell Long Barrow.name: Sherwell Long Barrow
Sherwell Long Barrow.description: This long barrow lies on a NW - SE axis, on private land in the hamlet of Sherwell (as spelled on my Ordnance Survey map (Outdoor Leisure 28 Dartmoor).  The hamlet has also been referred to as Sherrill.  The settlement is worth a visit just to see the quaint ancient houses, but I don't think you would be able to access the barrow without permission, and it was nearly 5 years ago that I visited with another member of our local dowsing group, following an invite from the lady owner.  This privacy would be respected by anyone reading this article, I hope.

Dunnabridge Pound.name: Dunnabridge Pound
Dunnabridge Pound.description: Dunnabridge Pound is situated almost dead centre of the wild moorland area of Dartmoor National Park, to the north of the B3357, between Dartmeet and Two Bridges.  It is very close to the road, and beside it is the ancient Dunnabridge Pound Farm.

St John's Well (Tavistock).name: St John's Well (Tavistock)
St John's Well (Tavistock).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

Holming Beam Stone.name: Holming Beam Stone
Holming Beam Stone.description: This relocated cup-marked stone on Dartmoor is set into a dry-stone wall on the eastern edge of Holming Beam plantation, some 250m north of B3357, 1M north of Princetown.

St Leonard's Well (Sheepstor).name: St Leonard's Well (Sheepstor)
St Leonard's Well (Sheepstor).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon. St LeonardÂ’s Well is to be found tucked in against the outside of the west wall of the churchyard of the parish church in the village of Sheepstor.  It is sheltered by what looks like, and in fact is, a fragment of the churchÂ’s old east window, removed during Victorian restorations.

Leech Wells.name: Leech Wells
Leech Wells.description: The Leech Wells are a wet, oozy place in the high walled, toadflax and aubretia hung, Leech Well Lane where three springs flow into granite troughs. There are three springs - one for healing, one for good luck and one simply as a place of veneration.

Meacombe Cist.name: Meacombe Cist
Meacombe Cist.description: Small burial chamber near Moretonhampstead in Devon.

Long Stone (Lyn Down).name: Long Stone (Lyn Down)
Long Stone (Lyn Down).description: Pair of Standing Stones in Devon

Drizzlecombe row 1.name: Drizzlecombe row 1
Drizzlecombe row 1.description: Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon. This is a 150 metre long stone row running in a southwesterly direction between the cairn 1 with its ring of stones at its upper end, and the lovely longstone at its lower end. The row is unusual in that it is part single and part a double row.

Drizzlecombe row 3.name: Drizzlecombe row 3
Drizzlecombe row 3.description: Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

Drizzlecombe cairn 2.name: Drizzlecombe cairn 2
Drizzlecombe cairn 2.description: Cairn with surrounding stone ring, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

Drizzlecombe cairn 3.name: Drizzlecombe cairn 3
Drizzlecombe cairn 3.description: Cairn with surrounding stone ring, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

Drizzlecombe.name: Drizzlecombe
Drizzlecombe.description: The complex of small stone circles, long rows, standing stones, cists and cairns located in this dramatic site is one of the most interesting in all of Europe.

Drizzlecombe Settlement.name: Drizzlecombe Settlement
Drizzlecombe Settlement.description: Ancient serttlements, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon.

Sharpitor NE.name: Sharpitor NE
Sharpitor NE.description: Double Stone Row on the northeastern slopes of Sharpitor in Devon

Merrivale NW.name: Merrivale NW
Merrivale NW.description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

Merrivale Centre S.name: Merrivale Centre S
Merrivale Centre S.description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

Merrivale Centre Row.name: Merrivale Centre Row
Merrivale Centre Row.description: Double Stone Row or Avenue, making up part of the Merrivale complex on the western slopes of Dartmoor in Devon

Merrivale Centre N.name: Merrivale Centre N
Merrivale Centre N.description: Cairn circle with central cist, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon

Merrivale NE circle.name: Merrivale NE circle
Merrivale NE circle.description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

Merrivale N circle.name: Merrivale N circle
Merrivale N circle.description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

Merrivale SW row 3.name: Merrivale SW row 3
Merrivale SW row 3.description: Merrivale SW stone row 3, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon.

Merrivale Cists.name: Merrivale Cists
Merrivale Cists.description: Burial Chamber, part of the Merrivale complex, on western Dartmoor, Devon.

Drizzlecombe cairn 13.name: Drizzlecombe cairn 13
Drizzlecombe cairn 13.description: Cairn, Cist and Possible Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon. The cairn is about 12 m diameter and 1 metre high, and has a large cist in the middle.

Drizzlecombe cairn 4.name: Drizzlecombe cairn 4
Drizzlecombe cairn 4.description: Cairn with surrounding stone ring, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

Drizzlecombe Giant's Basin.name: Drizzlecombe Giant's Basin
Drizzlecombe Giant's Basin.description: The Giants Basin is a large cairn making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon. It is positioned just to the southeast of the main Drizzlecombe stone rows, at the position between rows 1 and 2.

Drizzlecombe W row.name: Drizzlecombe W row
Drizzlecombe W row.description: Possible Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

Drizzlecombe row 2.name: Drizzlecombe row 2
Drizzlecombe row 2.description: Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

Shaugh Moor row.name: Shaugh Moor row
Shaugh Moor row.description: Stone Row with cairn circle at the uphill end, on a small remaining piece of open moorland in amongst the china clay working spoil tips of Shaugh Moor.

Shaugh Moor Circle.name: Shaugh Moor Circle
Shaugh Moor Circle.description: At the upper end of the stone row, not much remains of the cairn, but a few stones can be identified of its surrounding circle.

Fernworthy circle.name: Fernworthy circle
Fernworthy circle.description: Stone Circle in Devon. Located in the middle of Forestry Commission land, this is a pleasant circle to visit on the way to Grey Wethers Stone Circle. It is 19.8 (65 feet) across, slightly flattened East to West, and contains twenty-seven stones that are graded in height from north to south, at which position the tallest is about 1.2m (4 feet).

Fernworthy stone row SW.name: Fernworthy stone row SW
Fernworthy stone row SW.description: The Fernworthy southewestern stone row, stone row 3 is in a much better state of repair, possibly because of the lack of forest being grown on top of it! The row is a double row with the stones spaced about a metre apart, running in a north south alignment, of which about 35 metres can be determined.

Fernworthy stone row SE.name: Fernworthy stone row SE
Fernworthy stone row SE.description: The Fernworthy southeastern stone row, stone row 2, is found between the cairn 4 and the circle. The row is short and of small stones, hard to tell whether it is a single row, or a double row with little space between the two rows, rather like on Harford Hill.

Fernworthy stone row N.name: Fernworthy stone row N
Fernworthy stone row N.description: The northern stone row, or stone row 1, is to the north of the stone circle, and found by walking to the edge of the forest clearing and taking the trackway through to the next open area.

Fernworthy settlement.name: Fernworthy settlement
Fernworthy settlement.description: Within the confines of Fernworthy Forest on eastern Dartmoor in Devon are the remains of many groups of hut circles, damaged to a greater or lesser extent by the forest growth.

Challacombe rows.name: Challacombe rows
Challacombe rows.description: A rare triple Stone Row on the northern slopes of Challacombe Down, on Dartmoor.

Merrivale circle.name: Merrivale circle
Merrivale circle.description: An eleven-stone circle is a member of a group of several prehistoric structures: two stone circles, an avenue, a double row, a single row, a large damaged cist, standing stones and hut-circles.

Merrivale.name: Merrivale
Merrivale.description: Ceremonial Complex including two Multiple Stone Rows or Avenues, two more (at least) single stone rows, a stone circle, a large menhir (plus probably one more fallen), many burial cairns and cists, and an ancient settlement, on the western slopes of Dartmoor in Devon

Merrivale North Row.name: Merrivale North Row
Merrivale North Row.description: Double Stone Row making up part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon

Corringdon Ball.name: Corringdon Ball
Corringdon Ball.description: Corringdon Ball complex, southern Dartmoor, Devon SX666612

Corringdon Ball Central.name: Corringdon Ball Central
Corringdon Ball Central.description: Triple Stone Row almost 80m in length, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

Corringdon Ball South.name: Corringdon Ball South
Corringdon Ball South.description: Multiple Stone Row, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

Corringdon Ball N..name: Corringdon Ball N.
Corringdon Ball N..description: Single Stone Row, 132m in length, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

Corringdon Ball Cairns.name: Corringdon Ball Cairns
Corringdon Ball Cairns.description: There are the remains of several cairns just upslope from the Corringdon Ball complex, on southern Dartmoor in Devon in Devon.

Corringdon Ball SE.name: Corringdon Ball SE
Corringdon Ball SE.description: Cairn-circle at the northeastern end of the multiple stone rows, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

The Round Pound.name: The Round Pound
The Round Pound.description: One of the most impressive of ancient remains to be found on the lower northwest slopes of Kestor, near Batworthy Corner, is that of The Round Pound.

Scorhill.name: Scorhill
Scorhill.description: Scorhill Stone Circle and Standing Stone on Scorhill Down, northeast Dartmoor, with it's dramatic setting on the rugged moorlands makes this 26.8m (88-foot) circle a worthwhile visit.

Sherberton circle.name: Sherberton circle
Sherberton circle.description: Sherberton Stone Circle is approximately 30 metres in diameter with only 9 slabs still remaining in its northwest quadrant.

Sherberton Row.name: Sherberton Row
Sherberton Row.description: Sherberton Double Stone Row. Location SX63927328 on Dartmoor in Devon. First recognised by Brian Byng in 1997 and now listed.

Down Ridge.name: Down Ridge
Down Ridge.description: Down Ridge, or Hexworthy stone circle is on sloping ground on the northeastern flank of Down Ridge above Hexworthy, just above the enclosed areas below. There is not a huge amount left, and much of that is at the uphill side. It is 25m in diameter, 9 stones remain.

Conies Down.name: Conies Down
Conies Down.description: Conies Down Double Stone Row on Dartmoor is within the Merrivale military live firing range, so it is important that you check that there is no firing and that the range is open for visitors before you set off.

Hamel Down row.name: Hamel Down row
Hamel Down row.description: Stone Row (Alignment) in Devon, Reportedly destroyed, but now back from the dead !

Penn Beacon SW.name: Penn Beacon SW
Penn Beacon SW.description: Double Stone Row on the slopes of Penn Beacon, Dartmoor, Devon

Penn Beacon SE.name: Penn Beacon SE
Penn Beacon SE.description: Stone Row on the slopes of Penn Beacon, Dartmoor, Devon

Shovel Down stone circle.name: Shovel Down stone circle
Shovel Down stone circle.description: The Stone Circle at the Shovel Down complex is probably the oldest of the monuments in this ceremonial centre.

Shovel Down row 3.name: Shovel Down row 3
Shovel Down row 3.description: Double Stone Row between SX65908620 and SX65948603 making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

Shovel Down Settlement.name: Shovel Down Settlement
Shovel Down Settlement.description: Settlement in Devon. On the upper slopes of Shovel Down, to the west of the ceremonial complex of rows, circles, cairns and menhirs, can be found the remains of an ancient settlement.

Black Tor SW.name: Black Tor SW
Black Tor SW.description: Double stone row leading from the larger cairn to be found. This row is composed entirely of small unimpressive stones and is a powerful reminder that this type of monument is often far from visually spectacular.

Fernworthy Cairn E.name: Fernworthy Cairn E
Fernworthy Cairn E.description: Fernworthy Cairn 5 can be found less than a hundred metres to the east of the stone circle up a slight raise. It is up to 10 m diameter, and has a small 5 m diameter mound in the centre, surrounded by a flatter region and remains of a ring of surrounding stones.

Shovel Down.name: Shovel Down
Shovel Down.description: Near the northeastern corner of Dartmoor, to the west of the old stannary town of Chagford at Shovel Down, are a multitude of remains which together make up the Shovel Down complex of ceremonial sites.

Nine Stones (Belstone).name: Nine Stones (Belstone)
Nine Stones (Belstone).description: A nice neat little stone circle on the moors below Belstone Tor on the common to the south of the village of Belstone, Devon. This circle is almost certainly the remains of a round burial cairn, and traces of the burial chamber can be seen within the circle.

Shovel Down Fourfold Circle.name: Shovel Down Fourfold Circle
Shovel Down Fourfold Circle.description: Known as the Fourfold circle, the larger ring encloses 3 others, the innermost only 8 feet in diameter. An avenue of stones 505 feet long and 4 feet wide (Row 2) climbs to the S up a slope to approach the circle.

The Longstone (Shovel Down).name: The Longstone (Shovel Down)
The Longstone (Shovel Down).description: The lovely megalith known as The Longstone stands on the eastern slopes of Shovel Down, Dartmoor, Devon, and is part of the large Shovel Down group of ceremonial monuments

Shovel Down row 4.name: Shovel Down row 4
Shovel Down row 4.description: Double Stone Row between SX65928600 and SX66008593 making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

Shovel Down row 5.name: Shovel Down row 5
Shovel Down row 5.description: Double Stone Row between SX66008585 and SX66038568 making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

Shovel Down row 6.name: Shovel Down row 6
Shovel Down row 6.description: Destroyed Double Stone Row originally making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

Three Boys.name: Three Boys
Three Boys.description: At 1.4 metres long, this fairly large, almost fallen flat stone faces across the line at the southern end of Shovel Down row 6 on Dartmoor and was probably once a blocking stone. The stone is the single survivor of what was originally three stones.

Shovel Down row 1.name: Shovel Down row 1
Shovel Down row 1.description: Much ruined single Stone Row, 500m in length, SX66008625 to SX660857, which is a part of the Shovel Down Ceremonial centre on Dartmoor, Devon

Shovel Down row 7.name: Shovel Down row 7
Shovel Down row 7.description: Destroyed Double Stone Row originally making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

Trowlesworthy.name: Trowlesworthy
Trowlesworthy.description: Megalithic Complex in Devon. This is the overall site entry as there are many elements in the Trowlesworthy Complex. The two cairn stone rings and avenues described in the 4 other entries for Trowlesworthy plus several settlements and cairns. It truly is a megalithic 'complex'.

Trowlesworthy East row.name: Trowlesworthy East row
Trowlesworthy East row.description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

Sharpitor cairn circle.name: Sharpitor cairn circle
Sharpitor cairn circle.description: Cairn Circle and cist on the slopes of Sharpitor in Devon

Sharpitor NW double row.name: Sharpitor NW double row
Sharpitor NW double row.description: Situated on the north western slopes of Sharpitor, just to the south of the B3212 by Goatstone Pool, can be found the remains of a fairly ruinous double stone row and a single stone row.

Sharpitor NW single row.name: Sharpitor NW single row
Sharpitor NW single row.description: Situated on the north western slopes of Sharpitor, just to the south of the B3212 by Goatstone Pool, can be found the remains of a fairly ruinous double stone row and a single stone row.

Sharpitor W.name: Sharpitor W
Sharpitor W.description: Situated on the western slopes of Sharpitor, to the northwest of the B3212, are the remains of a nice single stone row.

Leeden Tor.name: Leeden Tor
Leeden Tor.description: Stone Row on the slopes of Leeden Tor, Dartmoor, Devon

Hart Tor North circle.name: Hart Tor North circle
Hart Tor North circle.description: Kerbed cairn at the head of the Hart Tor, North stone row, located on the south-western slopes of Hart Tor, just across the river Meavy from Black Tor

Hart Tor south row.name: Hart Tor south row
Hart Tor south row.description: Single Stone row situated on the south-western slopes of Hart Tor, just across the river Meavy from Black Tor.

Hart Tor north rows.name: Hart Tor north rows
Hart Tor north rows.description: Double stone row situated on the south-western slopes of Hart Tor, just across the river Meavy from Black Tor

White Moor Down.name: White Moor Down
White Moor Down.description: A truly lovely 20 metre diameter stone circle, miles away from any signs of modern life in the middle of the desolate Dartmoor.

White Moor Cairn.name: White Moor Cairn
White Moor Cairn.description: Much robbed cairn, 8.5 metres in diameter, which lies approximately mid way between the White Moor Stone circle, and the outlying White Moor Stone to the southeast.

White Moor Stone.name: White Moor Stone
White Moor Stone.description: 150 metres southeast of the White Moor Stone circle stands the White Moor Stone, which is more than 5 feet in height, and has been adapted as a parish boundary stone, with its parish marks cut into it.

Cosdon Hill Summit Cairns.name: Cosdon Hill Summit Cairns
Cosdon Hill Summit Cairns.description: The remains of five widely varying cairns can be found at the summit of Cosdon Hill, north Dartmoor, Devon, approximately following the ridge of the hill in a north-south manner.

Cosdon Hill Multiple Stone Rows.name: Cosdon Hill Multiple Stone Rows
Cosdon Hill Multiple Stone Rows.description: On a flattish shelf of land on the eastern side of Cosdon Hill, Dartmoor,  are the splendid remains of a cairn and treble stone row.

Cosdon Hill Cairn Circle.name: Cosdon Hill Cairn Circle
Cosdon Hill Cairn Circle.description: Cosdon Hill Cairn Circle lies at the upper end of the splendid Cosdon Hill triple row on a flattish shelf of land on the eastern side of Cosdon Hill

The Longstone (Piles Hill).name: The Longstone (Piles Hill)
The Longstone (Piles Hill).description: This large pointy topped stone just below the summit of Piles Hill, over 2 metres in height, leans at an angle although it has been only recently re-erected. It probably marked the northern end of the Butterdon Hill stone row.

Copplestone Cross.name: Copplestone Cross
Copplestone Cross.description: Probably the finest Saxon cross in south-western England. Granite cross shaft of the 10th century with carved interlace ornament on each face. Carvings also show a figure on horseback and two embracing figures. The cross is mentioned in a charter of 947.

Bennet's Cross.name: Bennet's Cross
Bennet's Cross.description: This is a lovely cross, believed to have been carved from a prehistoric menhir. It stands about 1.7 metres tall, and is just beside the B3212 road near its high point as it crosses the moor between Moretonhampstead and Postbridge, at an altitude of about 430 metres.

Cornridge SE.name: Cornridge SE
Cornridge SE.description:
Cairn and surrounding circle, Corn Ridge, Dartmoor, Devon.       

The remains of a nice large cairn can be found at the summit of Corn Ridge, about 10m diameter.

Sourton Tors Stone Circle.name: Sourton Tors Stone Circle
Sourton Tors Stone Circle.description: Stone Circle, Sourton Tors, Dartmoor, Devon

Harford S..name: Harford S.
Harford S..description:
Stone Rows, Harford Moor, Dartmoor, Devon SX652599 

On Harford Moor, the southwestern slopes below Piles Hill, near to the upper reaches of Butter Brook, are the remains of a couple of stone alignments, which are very close together.

Harford Moor N.name: Harford Moor N
Harford Moor N.description: Stone Rows, Harford Moor, Dartmoor, Devon SX652599. On Harford Moor, the southwestern slopes below Piles Hill, near to the upper reaches of Butter Brook, are the remains of a couple of stone alignments, which are very close together.

Butterbrook.name: Butterbrook
Butterbrook.description: Butterbrook Stone Rows, Harford Moor, Dartmoor, Devon SX652599

Cantrell.name: Cantrell
Cantrell.description: Cantrell Double Stone Row @ SX 6570 5717 has a cairn at the upper end which is on the skyline when viewed from the lower end of the row. The ruined cairn is 8m diameter & has a single slab at the centre in a hollow. Perhaps the remains of a burial kist.

Butterdon Stone Circle.name: Butterdon Stone Circle
Butterdon Stone Circle.description: The remains of the fantastic Butterdon Hill stone row run for nearly 2 kilometres across the moor in a roughly northerly direction from Butterdon Hill. The row starts at a cairn, which is situated just downslope to the north of the largest cairn on the hilltop.

Butterdon Hill Row.name: Butterdon Hill Row
Butterdon Hill Row.description: The second second longest on the moor. Single row 2000 metres long. Azimuth 2 variable. The row run runs along a high plateau almost North - South and starting from the southern end has a large terminal cairn surrounded by a circle of stones.

Glasscombe Ball North.name: Glasscombe Ball North
Glasscombe Ball North.description: The remains of this row can be found at the top of the ridge on the saddle between Glasscombe Ball and Piles Hill just to the east of the old tramway.

Glasscombe Corner Stone Row.name: Glasscombe Corner Stone Row
Glasscombe Corner Stone Row.description: On the eastern slopes of Piles Hill / Glasscombe Ball, just above Glasscombe Corner, is the remains of this combination double and single row of stones, about 180m long. The single section, which comprises the NE one-third of the total length, consists of slightly taller stones.

Glasscombe Ball NE.name: Glasscombe Ball NE
Glasscombe Ball NE.description: Glasscombe Stone Row Terminal Cairn (NE end). Also see

Hobajons Cross.name: Hobajons Cross
Hobajons Cross.description: Standing Stone with cross in Devon. This relatively large stone is part of the Butterdon Hill row, and has a simple cross carved into it on the western face.

Spurrells Cross Cairn Circle.name: Spurrells Cross Cairn Circle
Spurrells Cross Cairn Circle.description: Spurrells Cross Cairn Circle, Butterdon Hill, Dartmoor, Devon.

Butterdon Hill Barrow.name: Butterdon Hill Barrow
Butterdon Hill Barrow.description: Round Barrow on Butterdon Hill, Dartmoor, Devon, associated with nearby stone row.

Hook Lake Row.name: Hook Lake Row
Hook Lake Row.description: Remains of a double stone row which can be found on the eastern banks of the upper Erme valley in the middle of deepest southern Dartmoor.

Longstone (Challacombe).name: Longstone (Challacombe)
Longstone (Challacombe).description: Three kilometres from the nearest road and standing almost 3 metres high, the Longstone at Challacombe is the tallest stone on Exmoor.

Longstone Barrow Row.name: Longstone Barrow Row
Longstone Barrow Row.description: My notes for this say that there should be three stones in a row, with nowadays possibly one of them missing.

Great Links Tor Cairn.name: Great Links Tor Cairn
Great Links Tor Cairn.description: The remains of a large cairn can be found on the southwest slopes of Great Links Tor, about 15m diameter.

Gidleigh Chambered Cairn.name: Gidleigh Chambered Cairn
Gidleigh Chambered Cairn.description: A ruinous chambered cairn on the eastern side of Buttern Hill, west of Gidleigh village.

Sourton Tors Ring Cairns.name: Sourton Tors Ring Cairns
Sourton Tors Ring Cairns.description: Ring Cairns in Devon. The remains of two ring cairns can be seen on the slopes of Sourton Tors, just below the track which continues along from the remains of the tramway beyond the points, at which the railway reversed, the southernmost being slightly larger.

Sourton Tors Cairn.name: Sourton Tors Cairn
Sourton Tors Cairn.description: Cairn in Devon. The remains of a much destroyed cairn can be seen on the slopes of Corn Ridge, just above the track which passes up over the saddle between Sourton Tors and Corn Ridge.

Lundy Beacon Hill.name: Lundy Beacon Hill
Lundy Beacon Hill.description: Early Christian Sculptured Stone in Devon.

Lundy Settlement.name: Lundy Settlement
Lundy Settlement.description: At the extreme north end of Lundy Island is a prehistoric settlement believed to date from around 1000 BC.

Butterdon Hill Cairns.name: Butterdon Hill Cairns
Butterdon Hill Cairns.description: Cairns in Devon. At the summit of Butterdon Hill are two very large cairns, with others to be seen in the vicinity.

Spurrells Cross Row.name: Spurrells Cross Row
Spurrells Cross Row.description: Multiple Stone Rows or Avenue with terminal cairn in Devon

Woodbarrow Stone Setting.name: Woodbarrow Stone Setting
Woodbarrow Stone Setting.description: Out on the wet blowy moorland slopes of Exmoor to the south below Woodbarrow, is to be found a stone setting. Although I was not exactly sure what I was looking for, my notes said it was a double row.

Hurston Ridge.name: Hurston Ridge
Hurston Ridge.description: This fine double stone row lies approximatly NE/SW on a ridge at the south end of Chagford Common. It is best reached by parking near the Warren House Inn and walking up Water Hill, then follow the reave in a North Westerly direction.

Piles Hill W.name: Piles Hill W
Piles Hill W.description: This wonderful monument consists of an avenue of large stones, almost a kilometre in length running in an west to east direction over the top of the ridge of Piles Hill. The stones are generally between 1 and 2 metres in length, with many more than 2 metres.

Piles Hill NE.name: Piles Hill NE
Piles Hill NE.description: This wonderful monument consists of an avenue of large stones, almost a kilometre in length running in an west to east direction over the top of the ridge of Piles Hill. The stones are generally between 1 and 2 metres in length, with many more than 2 metres. The western end is at SX65056111 the eastern end at SX65886111

Corringdon Ball Tomb.name: Corringdon Ball Tomb
Corringdon Ball Tomb.description: The remains of Corringdon Ball chambered tomb are marked on the map as Long Barrow, and it is situated on the saddle of land between Corringdon Ball and Brent Fore Hill, not far from the cairn at the head of the Brent Fore row.

Oxenham Arms.name: Oxenham Arms
Oxenham Arms.description: An enormous and magnificent menhir built into the wall of a tremendous pub on the main street in the village of South Zeal, Devon. In fact, the pub is believed to have been built by monks in the twelfth century around the menhir.

Lidwell.name: Lidwell
Lidwell.description: This lonely spot is home to the remains of a small 13th century chapel. Although neatly fenced it is almost impossible to visit without Wellington boots as the whole area is running with water some of which flows from the well which is just on the right inside the iron fence. It used to be in a corner of the chapel before it became a ruin.

St Nectan's Well (Stoke).name: St Nectan's Well (Stoke)
St Nectan's Well (Stoke).description: Holy Well in Devon. St NectanÂ’s Well is on the site of the hut where the 6th century Welsh hermit, St Nectan, is said to have returned carrying his head after being set upon by thieves who beheaded him.

Beaples Hill.name: Beaples Hill
Beaples Hill.description: The Three Cornered Longstone is located at Beaples hill adjacent to the Tiverton to Barnstable link road. The bronze age Standing Stone remnant, lies SW of Knowstone Inner Moor & its Bronze age barrows.

Broadsands Chambered Tomb.name: Broadsands Chambered Tomb
Broadsands Chambered Tomb.description: A Neolithic chambered tomb or passage grave located on the southern slope overlooking Torbay coast at Broadsands. This megalithic chamber has a single parallel-sided entrance passage 3.8 metres long and 1.2 metres wide lined with alternating orthostats and dry stone walling set within a near circular cairn 12 metres in diameter at construction but later reduced to 7 metres north east by 9 metres east west.

Mattocks Down Stone.name: Mattocks Down Stone
Mattocks Down Stone.description: 2.5 metre tall Standing Stone near to Mattocks Down, which was fairly recently damaged by a lightning strike. There are four barrows nearby.

Five Barrows (Devon).name: Five Barrows (Devon)
Five Barrows (Devon).description: Five Barrows cemetery actually consists of nine barrows, one of which is a Bell barrow.

Buttern E.name: Buttern E
Buttern E.description: Buttern Stone Circle, SX 6494 8848, on the western slopes of Buttern Hill, northeast Dartmoor.

Kentisbury Down.name: Kentisbury Down
Kentisbury Down.description: SE from Combe Martin, along the A399, west of Parracombe, lie a group of standing stones. Off the A399, turn right onto Down Lane, which has a broad green strip up the middle for as far as you can see. We parked in front of gate, (a wind pump should be to your front left) to allow for space for other vehicles; however, we were there some 40 minutes (Helen remaining in the car), and did not see one other vehicle!

Damage Barton.name: Damage Barton
Damage Barton.description: Just a little to the west of Ilfracombe, lie 3 standing stones in close proximity to each other. Go west through the town centre, where the A399 becomes the A361. After a Church and Cemetery on your right on a bend, you will need to take a very sudden right hand turn towards Lee. One point of possible interest along the way, is a place called 'Whitestone', which is marked on the map. Around grid reference 497462, we saw an enormous white stone to the right of the road, before we descended a hill and it became obscured by a hedge. The stone was not marked on the map, but it looked a clear contender for a place worth looking at, access permitting.

Yar Tor SE.name: Yar Tor SE
Yar Tor SE.description: Much ruined triple stone row on the southeastern slopes of Yar Tor near Dartmeet in Devon

Trendlebere Down Stone Row Cairn.name: Trendlebere Down Stone Row Cairn
Trendlebere Down Stone Row Cairn.description: Cairn in Devon, associated with nearby stone row.

Ringmoor Down stone circle.name: Ringmoor Down stone circle
Ringmoor Down stone circle.description: On the top of the open moor that is Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy and its stone circle, this tremendous cairn circle and associated stone row are to be found, although they were "restored" in 1909, supposedly not very accurately.

Yellowmead row.name: Yellowmead row
Yellowmead row.description: Possible Multiple Stone Row in Devon

Museum of Barnstaple and North Devon.name: Museum of Barnstaple and North Devon

Spinsters' Rock.name: Spinsters' Rock
Spinsters' Rock.description: Burial Chamber (Dolmen) in Devon. The burial chamber is composed of a large capstone supported on three uprights.  The tomb collapsed in 1858 and was reconstructed soon afterwards, but not exactly as it had been originally.

Lower Piles.name: Lower Piles
Lower Piles.description: Cairn  with retaining kerb and with cist in Devon

Trowlesworthy East circle.name: Trowlesworthy East circle
Trowlesworthy East circle.description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

White Ridge.name: White Ridge
White Ridge.description: This stone row is 167m long, descending the hill from a ruined 8m diameter cairn [at SX65418165; 50.618984, -3.9039010]. 41 stones still show. The cairn is on the skyline when viewed from the bottom of the row.

Lakehead Hill 5.name: Lakehead Hill 5
Lakehead Hill 5.description: Cairn Circle on Lakehead Hill, near Postbridge, Dartmoor. One of several ancient sites on Lakehead Hill.

Buckland Ford.name: Buckland Ford
Buckland Ford.description: Cairn Circle on remote southern Dartmoor near to Buckland Ford.

Brown Heath Cairn and Cist.name: Brown Heath Cairn and Cist
Brown Heath Cairn and Cist.description: This encircled cairn and cist is featured on the Prehistoric Dartmoor Walks (PDW) website - see their entry for the

Lakehead Cairn Circle 1.name: Lakehead Cairn Circle 1
Lakehead Cairn Circle 1.description: Cairn Circle with central cist on Lakehead Hill, central Dartmoor, in Devon

Lakehead Hill 2.name: Lakehead Hill 2
Lakehead Hill 2.description: A fairly large cist box standing proud of the ground oat the western side of Lakehead Hill, at the edge of the forest. There is nothing too obvious of a cairn or circle surrounding it.

Farway &amp; Gittisham Hill Cemetery.name: Farway & Gittisham Hill Cemetery
Farway &amp; Gittisham Hill Cemetery.description: Barrow Cemetery of around thirty-three round barrows in Devon

Chapman Barrows.name: Chapman Barrows
Chapman Barrows.description: There are about half a dozen large round barrows in an east to west line running up the western slope and over the top of Chapman Down, and with a few other barrows also scattered about nearby making a total of eleven barrows in all.

Beardown Man.name: Beardown Man
Beardown Man.description: Standing Stone on Devil's Tor near the head of the Cowsic River, out in the midst of Dartmoor.

Furzehill Common 1.name: Furzehill Common 1
Furzehill Common 1.description: On the western slopes of Furzehill Common ridge, I first found a large boulder like stone, and with some further searching around, I found a sort of line of stones running down the side of the hill. I found two stones high up the slope which are spaced at about 10 metres from each other, (the uppermost fallen), and two more further down the slope, one of which is a nice stander.

Furzehill Common stone row.name: Furzehill Common stone row
Furzehill Common stone row.description: Here I found four little stumps of stone in a row, in a boggy hollow on top of the ridge. They are spaced 2.5, 5, 2.5 metres apart, suggesting a missing stone in between those I could find.

Hoccombe Coombe.name: Hoccombe Coombe
Hoccombe Coombe.description: A Multiple Stone Row in Devon, oncle thought to be a stone circle.

Cheriton Ridge 4.name: Cheriton Ridge 4
Cheriton Ridge 4.description: South along the Two Moors Way (Tarka Trail) along the top of the Cheriton Ridge, and a couple of kilometres out onto the open moorland can be found the remains of this stone setting.

Cheriton Ridge 2.name: Cheriton Ridge 2
Cheriton Ridge 2.description: South along the Two Moors Way (Tarka Trail) along the top of the Cheriton Ridge, and a couple of kilometres out onto the open moorland can be found the remains of this stone setting.

Yar Tor NW.name: Yar Tor NW
Yar Tor NW.description: Much ruined triple stone row on the southeastern slopes of Yar Tor near Dartmeet in Devon

Joan Ford Newtake row.name: Joan Ford Newtake row
Joan Ford Newtake row.description: Three slabs stand in a row on the slopes to the northwest of the Swincombe waterworks lake.

Thornworthy Little Common.name: Thornworthy Little Common
Thornworthy Little Common.description: Stone Row on the slopes of the Thornworthy valley on Exmoor.

Cheriton Ridge stone row.name: Cheriton Ridge stone row
Cheriton Ridge stone row.description: South along the Two Moors Way (Tarka Trail) along the top of the Cheriton Ridge, and a couple of kilometres out onto the open moorland can be found the small remains of this stone row.

Lakehead Hill.name: Lakehead Hill
Lakehead Hill.description: This site page serves as the main page for complex Lakehead Hill area, as it has a number of ancient monuments within a small area. If you look below, you will see photographs for each of the different sites in this vicinity. Each of the individual sites has its own separate site pages with more information, and for you to submit photographs and visit reports to - see the 'nearby sites' list below.

Lakehead Hill W.name: Lakehead Hill W
Lakehead Hill W.description: A single stone row, orientated east - west, lies just to the north of the summit of Lakehead Hill on Dartmoor in Devon.

Lakehead Hill E.name: Lakehead Hill E
Lakehead Hill E.description: A short stone row leads up a circle of stones surrounding a covered kist. The row has suffered the fate of being excavated and 'restored' in 1895 by the Dartmoor Exploration Committee, so many of the features seen today are unlikely to have been original. Yet the kink in the row as it approaches the circle is similar to many other rows on the moors. There were no finds recovered.

Down Tor stone row.name: Down Tor stone row
Down Tor stone row.description: Down Tor (Hingston Hill) stone row, SX 5902 6939 to SX 5868 6927.

Collard Tor W.name: Collard Tor W
Collard Tor W.description: A pair of single stone rows each leading downslope (south) from a separate cairn. The rows lead through an area of clutter making them difficult to define in places.

Collard Tor E.name: Collard Tor E
Collard Tor E.description: A pair of single stone rows each leading downslope (south) from a separate cairn. The rows lead through an area of clutter making them difficult to define in places.

Cholwichtown stone row.name: Cholwichtown stone row
Cholwichtown stone row.description: There was once a 217 metre long single Stone Row here with 91 remaining large stones, before it was excavated in 1961 before total destruction as part of the china clay works. Only the rows on

Burford Down Stone Row.name: Burford Down Stone Row
Burford Down Stone Row.description: Stone Row in Devon with cairn circle: one of the finest in Dartmoor, shows evidence of recent damage by whatever farmer is running huge tractors across the fields.

Woodbarrow Hangings.name: Woodbarrow Hangings
Woodbarrow Hangings.description: Stone setting to the north of Woodbarrow on Exmoor, just inside the Devon side of the border.

Winnaway.name: Winnaway
Winnaway.description: Stone setting on the northern slopes below The Chains of Exmoor with 4 remaining stones.

White Ladder.name: White Ladder
White Ladder.description:
Double Stone Row in Devon. During 2006 the particularly dry conditions have caused peat shrinkage and this has in turn led
to the re-emergence of the Whiteladder Stone Row on Five Barrows Hill, first discovered by Hazel Eardley-Wilmot in
1975. At least 4 pairs of stones not visible in May 2006 had emerged by the end of the summer, confirming that
Whiteladder is a double stone row of local slate and lumps of white quartz.

Hoaroak 1.name: Hoaroak 1
Hoaroak 1.description: This is a nice little setting of stones, mostly on open grassland, making it easy to see and find! I found six little stones in a D shape, with two or three more downhill from them, plus a few more stones scattered about seemingly randomly.

Higher White Tor stone row.name: Higher White Tor stone row
Higher White Tor stone row.description: Remains of a double stone row to the south of Higher White Tor on Dartmoor

Laughter Tor row 1.name: Laughter Tor row 1
Laughter Tor row 1.description: A large standing stone and remains of two double stone rows can be found here on Laughter Tor.

Stannon Newtake West Cairn and double ro.name: Stannon Newtake West Cairn and double row

Trendlebere Down.name: Trendlebere Down
Trendlebere Down.description: Double Stone Row in Devon. The approach to the stone row is down a slope from the road, under Black Hill. Apparently an associated cairn was situated 10m north of the road, and is "barely recognizable, merely a low crescent of earth with a few stones embedded in the turf." [Butler].

Trowlesworthy West row.name: Trowlesworthy West row
Trowlesworthy West row.description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

Ringmoor Down Stone Row.name: Ringmoor Down Stone Row
Ringmoor Down Stone Row.description: On the top of the open moor that is Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy and its stone circle, this tremendous cairn circle and 369m long stone row are to be found, although they were "restored" in 1909, supposedly not very accurately, and as a result little is known as to its original length or format.

Joan Ford Newtake W.name: Joan Ford Newtake W
Joan Ford Newtake W.description: Joan Ford Newtake W, a little cairn or stone circle at the corner of the enclosure wall with its gated entrance.

Buttern W.name: Buttern W
Buttern W.description: In the late nineteenth century, Worth reported a second stone circle, Â“about 20 metres in diameter, a short distance from Buttern Hill circle, on the slope to the westward, with 4 or 5 stones standingÂ”.

Deadman's Bottom Cists.name: Deadman's Bottom Cists
Deadman's Bottom Cists.description: Two cisted grave cairns, All elements of the two cisted graves appear to be present, The Southern cist has a cairn circle around it, The Northern cist is on the edge of a cairn. At the East and West of the cists are small enclosures.

Larkbarrow Corner Stone Setting.name: Larkbarrow Corner Stone Setting
Larkbarrow Corner Stone Setting.description: A square shaped setting (fourth stone broken off at ground level) with a flat stone in the middle.

Stalldown Cairn Circle.name: Stalldown Cairn Circle
Stalldown Cairn Circle.description: This small circle lies adjacent to the impressive Stalldown row, and indeed two of the outer stones are more appropriate to the row alignment. One of these stones lies flat, while the other is a pointed pillar aligned with the row.

Stonetor Hill Stone Ring Cairn Circle.name: Stonetor Hill Stone Ring Cairn Circle

Trowlesworthy West circle.name: Trowlesworthy West circle
Trowlesworthy West circle.description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

Harbourne Head B.name: Harbourne Head B
Harbourne Head B.description: Embanked Cairn Circle / Stone Circle in Devon

Joan Ford Newtake E.name: Joan Ford Newtake E
Joan Ford Newtake E.description: Remains of a well defined circular cairn, with a clear 8 metre diameter kerb of stones around the outside. Centrally is a large cist of which all four side slabs remain, as well as the displaced capstone.

Mardon Down S.name: Mardon Down S
Mardon Down S.description: Mardon Down Stone Circle is the largest on Dartmoor at 38 metres diameter and nowadays clear to see but in a very ruinous state, with only 2 or 3 stones still standing of what was probably once between 60 and 70.

Bellever Tor 2.name: Bellever Tor 2
Bellever Tor 2.description: This encircled cairn is recorded as

Seven Stones (Devon).name: Seven Stones (Devon)
Seven Stones (Devon).description: Site of what was believed to be a bronze age Stone Circle, which was dug up and removed to become a garden feature in 1830.

Treeland Brake.name: Treeland Brake
Treeland Brake.description: Treeland Brake stone row was destroyed by agricultural activity in 1977.
